column1: Filmmaker Robert Greenwald has effectively made mincemeat of his targets in a couple of recent fiery documentaries - Rupert Murdoch and the FOX Network in "Outfoxed: Rupert Murdoch's War on Journalism"
column2: and the Bush administration in "Uncovered: The War on Iraq". His latest is no exception as he lays into Wal-Mart
column3: its CEO Lee Scott and Sam Walton's heirs in this probing 2005 critique of corporate injustice. Instead of providing a single narrative voice
column4: Greenwald structures his film as a series of vignettes focusing on discrete instances of where Wal-Mart has violated fair market practices
column5: passed over women and minorities for leadership positions
column6: restricted movements toward employee unionization
column7: taken advantage of cheap labor in China and India
column8: and disregarded environmental standards.  The grievances seem endless
column9: and the film even discloses the embarrassingly paltry amounts each Walton family member has given to charitable causes (compared to Bill Gates
column10: of course). The most touching episodes focus on victims like Red Esry
column11: who are experiencing the closure of their multi-generational small businesses in small towns where Wal-Mart opens and cannibalizes the competition. Much of the treatment seems ham-fisted
column12: especially in the juxtaposition of Wal-Mart commercials and in-house training videos within the context of those being crushed by the corporation's economic clout. Moreover
column13: the one segment about the rape of an employee in a parking lot
column14: while horrific
column15: seems more generic in nature than Wal-Mart's accountability in the incident. The abundance of conjecture and the lack of attributable facts tend to affect some of the film's credibility.  However
column16: Greenwald makes his points with clarity. Especially effective is the use of archived footage of Scott asserting to a massive audience of his employees that Wal-Mart has done nothing but good for the economy
column17: even though many of them have to go on welfare to get medical care. The film ends with a montage of people who have successfully lobbied against the construction of stores in their towns. At the same time
column18: Greenwald has not made a monomaniacal diatribe
column19: as the takeaway never feels like the destruction of Wal-Mart but more a call for a severe overhaul of their internal practices. The filmmaker has certainly come a long way since his 1980 feature film debut
column20: the ludicrous "Xanadu"
column21: and he seems to be continuing his streak of confronting those corrupted by their power.   The DVD has several extras
column22: the best being a twenty-minute making-of featurette and a separate 16-minute short
column23: "The Big Meeting"
column24: on how the film came about. Greenwald also provides a commentary track
column25: though much of what he shares can be gleaned from the featurettes. There are a couple of deleted segments that do seem redundant if they were included in the movie (one set in Quebec
column26: the other in England)
column27: as well as a brief clip of local religious leaders condemning Wal-Mart's practices. Lastly
column28: there are several fitfully funny Wal-Mart commercial parodies that apparently served as commercials for the documentary. Those looking for a more-in-depth analysis of Wal-Mart's business impact may want to read Charles Fishman's "The Wal-Mart Effect: How the World's Most Powerful Company Really Works - and How It's Transforming the American Economy"

I found this to be one of the most interesting books I have ever read. For me it's a revolutionary work in the sense that very rarely do books such as this come into my life -- maybe once every five years -- and have the ability to forever change the way I think about the world. And as with all such important books
column2: it is iconoclastic and will not please everyone. Some will no doubt hate it
column3: but most of the objectivist academics have no doubt long since dismissed it as nonsense. Most assuredly it is not without its faults. For example
column4: Lakoff tends to rail a bit  much against what he calls "objectivist" viewpoints (those who espouse some flavor of the correspondence theory of truth)
column5: which includes pretty much all of the present day scientific community  as well as the majority of Anglo-American analytic philosophers. In addition
column6: the book is admittedly long-winded and a little repetitious in places. By the time I had gotten to the end of the second case study
column7: I was totally burned out and could not continue any further. But it wasn't disenchantment with the book so much as the desire to just move on to something else. I have yet to read the third case study
column8: but I will eventually. In fact
column9: I know that I will come back to this book many times in the future to refer to the numerous insights which lie scattered everywhere throughout the text.  Contrary to what you may have been told
column10: Lakoff is NOT an egotistical academic. He is quick to give credit and praise to others for many or most of the ideas contained in this work. Nor is he vain and arrogant; on occasion he even makes fun of himself. He does not talk down to the reader
column11: but his expectation is that you are able to follow his argument
column12: which is intelligent-undergraduate level. To be sure
column13: he has not tried to water down the ideas to appeal to a wide audience of couch potatoes.  I especially like the format of this book: the larger type is easy on my older eyes; excellent paper quality
column14: generous margins
column15: little or no typos: All make for a first-rate reading experience
column16: a real treat. The generous margins are useful for jotting down quick notes on the side for future reference
column17: as I did repeatedly thoughout this book.   I will end with one example of the many insights that fill this fascinating book: Viewing truth as a radial concept forms the foundation for a mature relativism "Because
column18: as we have seen
column19: truth cannot be characterized as correspondence to a physical reality
column20: we must recognize truth as a human concept
column21: subject to the laws of human thought... There are central and non-central truths. The central truths are characterized in terms of directly understood concepts
column22: concepts that fit the pre-conceptual structure of experience. Such concepts are (a) basic-level concepts in the physical domain
column23: and (b) general schemas emerging from experience...." The fact that there are central truths and non-central truths means that by realizing that the truths we live by are not central
column24: we can gain an appreciation of and respect for the truths others live by.   In summary
column25: this book held my attention for more than 400 pages
column26: was thought-provoking
column27: challenging
column28: rewarding
column29: and one of the most satisfying intellectual experiences I have encountered to date. I strongly recommend it

column1: This edition of Dreiser's JENNIE GERHARDT attempts to "correct" the text that appeared in 1911 when the book was first published. Back then the editors at Harper's agreed to publish the novel only if they could make substantial changes to the text
column2: softening Dreiser's criticisms of organized religion and the rich
column3: and diluting the "immoral" behavior of the main character. Dreiser reportedly didn't like the changes
column4: fought to get some of them re-instated
column5: but eventually had to yield since no other publisher would touch the book. Using preserved typescripts
column6: this edition is closer to the one Dreiser submitted before cuts were made.  Jennie Gerhardt has an out-of-wedlock child by Senator Brander
column7: which she is able to keep secret from the wealthy socialite Lester Kane
column8: whom she takes up with. He finds out about the child
column9: however
column10: and is unaffected by the news. He continues to live with her in a complicated arrangement
column11: until Jennie finds out that Lester's father will basically disinherit him if he doesn't stop living with her and forces him to leave (echoes of WASHINGTON SQUARE by James and the subsequent movie version THE HEIRESS here). He marries Letty Gerald
column12: a woman from his own social class
column13: but is miserable. When he becomes ill and is alone
column14: he summons Jennie and declares his true love for her.  The novel is an interesting one. Lester is a pessimistic
column15: cynical
column16: atheistic man while Jennie is much simpler and has a mystical belief in the goodness of life. The "battleground" on which these opposing beliefs are fought over is made fascinating by Dreiser. Also Lester's struggle with his own wealthy class system
column17: which he is never comfortable with and rebels against
column18: is handled admirably and honestly by the author (it became a major theme in fiction by WW I). This was Dreiser's second novel after SISTER CARRIE; it's not as good as that first book
column19: but it's a solid work of fiction nonetheless

column1: Dear fellow readers: 	The subject of mass and heat transfer is very involved

column3: hence it is easily understood. As the chapters develop
column4: other concepts such as thermodynamics
column5: solids
column6: and fluids come in to discussion. For this reason I recommend that any one who wishes to read this book
column7: have a firm grasp on these subjects. These sections are far and few in between
column8: so a reader can further develop their understanding with out much difficulty. As the title states the book is about both heat and mass transfer. It is interesting to note that
column9: although these subjects are fundamentally different the calculations are very similar thanks to dimensionless numbers. The book does a very good job of explaining and relating these topics to each other. In my personal opinion
column10: if there is one book that should be bought that encompasses these subjects

After seeing "The Right Stuff" I became intrigued with the Mercury Seven astronauts and wanted to read everything I could about them and when I saw John Glenn's autobiography I immediately snatched it up and pored through the pages!  What a great and exciting life John lived!  Poring through the pages I hung on every word and lived his experiences vicariously as he described them...I can only imagine how he felt when he was picked to be one of the 7 Mercury astronauts...He was in a elite group that was beginning to embark on a major adventure into a new frontier...How exciting that must have been!  John's book to me was better than the movie..He talks bout his childhood days and test pilot years and ends with a wonderful passage on flying back into space again at the ripe old age of 77..What an inspiring book!  If you are looking for inspiration..pick this book up and read about ambition and hard work and focus ande see what all these things can do for your life!  John...thanks for being a great role model

I had just recently seen a Lange exhibit when I bought this wonderful book.   It starts with an essay on Lange by Robert Coles.   Then it moves into her photographs and her own words.   Her work is beautiful on its own
column2: but to have the photographs and her philosophy side by side is an enriching experience.   The photographs fill the entire book so it's a great read and a nice coffee table book.   The images are primarily from her depression photos
column3: but there are also pictures from around the world
column4: her family and her early portraits.   I also like that they included photographs of her and her oak trees.   Dorothea Lange was a woman with such a unique perspective on life.   I feel that this book does an excellent job of presenting her work

column1: Silver
column2: the girlchild of an unwed mother and a seaman grows up on the seacliffs overlooking the fishing town of Salts in a house perched so precariously that all the furniture has to be nailed down and Silver and her mother have to rope themselves together to keep from falling to their deaths. Even their dog evolves deformed legs to navigate the steeply leaning floor! When her mother dies in an accident
column3: Silver is apprenticed to an old lighthousekeeper named Pew
column4: and begins to learn not only the beauty of this simple but important job
column5: but also a little of the history of the family that built it. What follows are interlocking and parallel narratives of Silver's urge to find the meaning of her life and that of Babel Dark
column6: friend of Darwin and Robert Louis Stevenson
column7: who lived a double life while serving as the town's clergyman.   Lighthousekeeping is a nice book that recalls not only classic literature but also allows Winterson to use her penchant for creating half-real neverlands that somehow find solid ground in the real world. Many aspects of this novel are fairytale-like and the interweaving of historical personages and the connection of names to Treasure Island lend it an even more dream-like quality that recalls poetry more than prose. In some of Winterson's other works
column8: her pseudo-gravitas is invested too much in the lyrical nature of her words to the detriment of the storytelling. But Lighthousekeeping is a rousing success. A good book.

Dr. Strand provides the reader with priceless information that will empower you to take charge of your health
Daniel Hillel's
column2: Out of the Earth: Civilization and the Life of the Soil
column3: stands as a definite "must read" for all of us. Although science-based throughout
column4: this book reads like a mystery novel as Hillel traces man's relationship to the soil over the centuries. Ultimately
column5: he shows us the destruction wrought on civilizations through neglect and ignorance of the soil
column6: proving in the end
column7: as we have somewhat suspected all along
column8: every civilization is built from the soil--more literally than is often recognized.  Hillel's understanding
column9: and empathy
column10: comes through distinctively in this compelling narrative
column11: which he introduces as "not a strictly dispassionate exposition."   Drawing on his background in education
column12: he begins with a clear and concise introduction to soil science. From there
column13: he takes us along on a journey across our planet and through time to look at the soil with a new appreciation.  Hillel is the best kind of writer - seductively informative and a passionate observer. He brings to his pages an affinity for his subject that could make even a debutante  enamored of the very ground upon which we all walk. Hillel details soil management in Israel where he served in different positions with the government.  He is intimately familiar with desert soil management
column14: but he ranges far and wide beyond the deserts - into the rain forest as well as the plains of the American Midwest. His experience and his vision encompass the entire earth
column15: and his examples are born from every continent. His clear and instructive text is easily digested; his examples are well thought and  concise. This book will repay your investment of time and money with a better understanding of the soil you walk daily - that "dirt" you dig out from under your nails after a day in the garden. I appreciate even more the soil which serves as the foundation of my home and upon which the culture and all that we as a society have built - the thin crust that sustains all the inhabitants of Earth; that delicate layer of the Earth in which we grow our plants and bury all our dead. We live and die as beings
column16: societies and civilizations
column17: in conjunction with the care we bestow upon the soil or withhold from it. We may fare no better than our ancestors in our care of the soil
column18: but it will not be from ignorance with books like Hillel's around.  This book sits handily on my bookshelf; I take it down and allow it to open to a page to "spot-peruse." It has become pivotal in my thinking about soil
column19: water and civilization

For many years I have relied on War & Change in World Politics as a structural guide to examining international relations.  Gilpin's classic work provides
column2: both clear historical and theoretical support to augument  his argument.  His thoughts reside firmly in the realist tradition
column3: but  adds to the richness of that paradigm through focusing on transition.  Gilpin correctly argued that
column4: Throughout history a principal objective  of states has been the conquest of territory in order to advance economic,  security, and other interests.  Whether by means of imperialist subjugation  of one people by another or by annexation of contiguous territory, states  in all ages have sought to enlarge their control over territory and, by  implication, their control over the international system.  For this reason,  a theory of international political change must of necessity also be a  theory of imperialism and political integration.(23) The firm goal of  Gilpin is to creat a theory of the transition of power relations. I believe  that he has provided the initial steps through his courageous attempt to  provide framework developing a theory of change.   I first read War &  Change while residing in Western and Central Europe, from 1989 to 1999. I  was at the tearing down of the Berlin Wall, The Gulf War, and witnessed the  collapse of the Soviet Union and the reunification of Germany.  Gilpin's  book provided structure to my studies and my personal search for  understanding of the dynamics of these profound changes in societies. I  evaluated theories of economism, based on American capitalism versus  European and Japanese socialism and the belief in a new tri-polar order and  found them theoretically broken down in War & Change.  Gilpin argued  that,Although multipolar systems can become tripolar
column5: the more usual  occurrence is for bipolar systems to become tripolar
column6: and as Waltz  correctly observed
column7: tripolar systems tend to be the most unstable os  all....Thus the emergence of a powerful China
column8: Japan
column9: or united Europe  would undoubtedly prove to be a destabilizing factor in contemporary world  politics."(91)  The explosion of the Internet changed for many the  equation of power.  However
column10: the technological catch up tactics of Japan in  the 1980s had many Americans worrying that it's comparative advantage was  being lost.  The Internet will decrease the curve and the trajectory of  technological catchup policies. Take a read of pages 173-178 to fully  appreciate Gilpin's analysis of pre-Internet military and technological  trends. The ideas of democracy as the only legitimste form of government  were dismayed by my real life experiences and I found support and faults in  my analysis of this situation in Gilpin's work. In closing
column11: I believe that  Gilpin needed to concentrate his argument more on a particular structure of  change.  However
column12: because of the wide range of issues that increase the  factors of change and the trajectories of states an explanation of change  that requires this drift was almost a necessity.      For any student of  international relations or history War & Change in World Politics is  rich in references and advice for structuring an analysis.  My belief is  that this is a fundamental book in understanding the changes occurring now  and that will be in the future

column4: both internal and external.  He stated that all nations were once at this level of Pre-history
column5: where no king could last more than a year.  But China was the first nation to make One but only One Person free
column6: namely
column7: the Emperor.   This was the beginning of History.  From this point Hegel traces those nations which increased Freedom slowly - from Egypt to Assyria to Babylon to Persia to Greece to Rome to Spain and then Europe as we know it today.  The Idea of a Free Republic was born in Greece
column8: but was first made material in Rome.  Caesar opposed the Republic because he knew that the fullness of time had not yet come for it; so he opened up barbarian Europe instead.  The Free Republic eventually grew to a point where a great
column9: courageous World Historical Individual
column10: Napoleon Bonaparte
column11: overthrew the Medieval structures and paved the way for the eventual abolition of Slavery.  Hegel was an Abolitionist and lived to see England and Spain renounce Slavery

Marvin Gayes' untimely death in 1984 left a big void in music. Marvin Gaye had become one of the most influential singer and songwriters in soul music history. His diligent work had tremendous depth
column2: making profound political statements and social commentary as well as having a poignant and spiritual edge.   Marvin Gayes' recording career spans back to the dawn of the swinging sixties when Motown Records was beginning to make its mark in the world by becoming commonly known as "the sound of young America". The fantastic Stubborn Kind Of Fellow was one of his very best early hits. The formulaic though enduring Motown sound is fully at work on this classic with Gayes' distinctive vocals seamlessly surfboarding along the somwhat complex musical arrangements.   Hitch Hike
column3: Can I Get A Witness? and Too Busy Thinking About My Baby also encapsulates that familiar and distinct Motown sound of its golden era in the 1960's and all three are instantly contagious from the musical arrangements to gayes rocketing vocal performances that was in a class and style of its own.   During Motowns golden era of the 1960's
column4: Gaye worked with many of the labels most talented female singers. His phenomenal duet with the underated Kim Weston on the sparse
column5: It Takes Two
column6: sounds just as fresh and as vibrant as it was back then. But it was the divine Tammi Terrell (who was married to David Ruffin
column7: one-time lead singer of The Temptations) that he found his perfect duet partner.   Gaye and Terrell cut many albums and succesful hit singles together with their diverse blend of harmonies gelling neatly into the sexually sizzling productions. Some of their greatest duets include You're All I Need To Get By
column8: Ain't No Mountain High Enough ( the latter being a total contrast to the more famous version Diana Ross took to the top of the charts in 1970)
column9: You Ain't Livin Till Your Lovin' and The Onion Song.   Gayes recording work in the late 60's vastly matured growing much more unique and phenomenal. He really hits his stride on the masterpiece
column10: chart-topping mega-classic
column11: I Hear It Through The Grapevine. The compelling opening interlude leads into a rocking and sparse production with Gayes stirring
column12: soulful delivery complimenting the startling arrangements. Gaye really carries off I Heard It Through The Grapevine with style and finesse and this was but a mere taste of things to come.   Whilst his recording work progressed the sound of his music became more refined and stylized. He delivered what was possibly his greatest ever album in 1971 with What's Going On. That album neraly didn't happen as Motown boss Berry Gordy was unsure as to how his buying public might react to Gayes new
column13: creative force. Well
column14: if anything
column15: this merely fuelled Gayes record sales and critics alike joined in to praise the genius. What's Going On completely shook off his more familiar sound of the 60's
column16: exploring relevant environmental issues that also made some form of political comment as well as profound social commentary.   Gaye is put more in touch with his spiritual side on the timeless and poignant Mercy
column17: Mercy Me which
column18: with its rolling arrangements that has a really sharp
column19: soulful edge
column20: conveys Gayes vocal power which was simply going from strength to strength.   In 1973 he recorded a successful album of duets with the queen of Motown
column21: Diana Ross. The highlight of this project was the breathtaking
column22: You Are Everything. From that magical
column23: exotic opening intro to the fittingly refined vocal delivery of Ross to Gayes more forceful
column24: aggressive delivery
column25: You Are Everything is THE ultimate love duet!   The evocative Lets Get It On taking from the excellent album of the same name
column26: is one of my own personal favourite tracks. Gaye is in full romantic mood here with his exuberant delivery sounding highly sexually charged. This merley coats the smooth arrangements that features glorious saxophone interludes played at various points on the recording.   Gaye moved into funkier terriotry in the late 70's and reached its pinnacle on tracks such as the satrtlinglyeffective Got To Give It Up. With its multi-layered musical arrangements
column27: dubbed crowd noises that sounds as though it was recorded live in a nightclub to Gayes impeccable delivery
column28: it perfectly demenonstrated Gayes wonderful craft of versatlity.   One of Gayes last signature tunes had to be the timeless
column29: sensual and utterly divine Sexual Healing. Gayes raw
column30: earthy delivery rides along the state-of-the-art production and this was featured on his last studio album
column31: Midnight Love which was his first (and last) for CBS Records following his departure from Motown records.   This two Cd collection collects together all of these classics that are all compelling musically and really give you an understanding as to why his work has remained unparralled and such an inspiration to todays new generation of wannabe soul/r&b singers. ESSENTIAL!   Ian Phillips

column1: Steven Ozment's A Mighty Fortress is the best comprehensive survey of German History I've ever read.  If I were to teach a class on this subject
column2: his would be my textbook.  The extensive "notes" section offers the reader a variety of resources to expand knowledge in particular areas.  Ozment offers a balanced and intelligent perspective on a people who have long been a source of high achievement but also profound disillusionment in the European experience.  Without resorting to ideology or popular cant
column3: he gives us the foundational understanding to find both unifying themes and surprising variations.  He handles this massive and not a little controversial subject so well that I bought several copies as gifts

This book debunks many assumptions we have about help among poor people.  It presents vividly what happens when there are very few resources and  people must make heartwrenching decisions whether to help their mom with a  small loan of money or their children with school supplies. The poor often  don't have enough resources to help everyone and end up in difficult  situations that sometimes lead to tension. This book is an eye opener!  Anyone working with poor and disadvantaged populations should read it

column1: Fascism is one of the more complex political movements of the past century and one of the more difficult to satisfyingly define.  Philosophers sometimes seek the necessary and sufficient conditions for defining some term or concept.  The problem with fascism is that while there are a number of necessary conditions
column2: they are not in themselves sufficient in designating a movement as fascist.  Fascism is always ultranationalistic
column3: racist
column4: and anti-liberal
column5: but these are features it holds in common with a host of other right wing political movements.  In the end
column6: identifying a movement as fascist is more of an art than a science
column7: akin to the famous definition of obscenity by U. S. Supreme Court Justice Potter Stewart:  "I know it when I see it."  Kevin Passmore's fine book can help one know it when one sees a fascist movement.    It is important to understand this movement for a host of reasons
column8: many of them historical but some of them contemporary.  For instance
column9: calling someone a fascist has become a commonplace of contemporary political vituperation.  In the 2004 election I heard a number of people call Bush a fascist
column10: and while he holds a few positions in common with fascism
column11: they are in the end very few and the differences significant.  Less understandably
column12: I heard more than one right wing commentator call Kerry a fascist
column13: which is beyond comprehension
column14: since he does not espouse a single position that connects with what we understand as fascism.  So we really do need to understand what it means when we properly identify someone as a fascist.  Passmore's approach is primarily to discuss a host of national situations from a historical perspective that were at the time either self-identified as fascist or
column15: in the wake of WW II and the utter discreditation of fascism
column16: that share a significant number of features with pre-WW II fascism.  Obviously this approach means discussing Italian and German fascism
column17: but Passmore also spends a good amount of time on nations that will be unfamiliar to all but serious students of Eastern Europe
column18: such as Romania.  The picture that gradually emerges of fascism is of a movement that is anti-modern
column19: rascist
column20: masculine and anti-feminist
column21: corporatist
column22: rabidly nationalistic
column23: rural rather than urban
column24: largely undemocratic
column25: leans towards a dictatorship
column26: tends to be anti-free market and at the same time anti-trade union
column27: and paramilitary in nature.  What can be bewildering is that not every incarnation of fascism can be characterized by all of these features.  This is less true of pre-WW II fascism than post-war
column28: when movements that are largely fascist have been forced to espouse democratic principles and even claim not to be racist.  In the end
column29: what one gains is not a crystal clear of what is or is not fascism
column30: but a general impression of what might count as a fascist movement.  This is not a well-written book
column31: which is the only complaint I would like to make about it.  The structure is awkward and one chapter does not naturally flow into one another.  There seems to be little rhyme or reason why one bit of the subject is dealt with in one part of the book and not another.  Furthermore
column32: Passmore never really states clearly what he sees as lying at the heart of fascism.  I managed to figure out what he meant by typing out various identifying characteristics as I read through the text
column33: but unless one undertakes some such exercise
column34: one could end the book a bit confused about the whole matter.  Had the book been more clearly structured
column35: it would be a far more valuable introduction to the subject.  In the end
column36: one does get a good sense about fascism
column37: but only if one is willing to work hard towards that end.  The author doesn't help the reader as much as he might have.  Nonetheless
column38: I strongly recommend this book.  Although we are unlikely to see the kind of fascist movements that we saw in the interwar years
column39: it represents tendencies in political thinking that have never really disappeared and persist even today.  We need to be sensitive to these tendencies and prepared to deal with them in the future

column1: Lara's life is perfect.  She has everything going for her: she is one of the most popular girls in school
column2: she is beautiful
column3: she has a wonderful boyfriend and her family is great.  Even though she is in high school
column4: her father still calls her his princess and tells her all the time how beautiful she is.  Her mother is thin and beautiful
column5: too
column6: and supports Lara as she enters and wins beauty pageants.  The best night of Lara's life is the night she wins the title of Homecoming Queen as a junior.  She has officially been voted by her peers the most beautiful and the most popular girl in school.  The only thing that makes this night slightly less than perfect is the fact that she tries to help Patty
column7: the fattest girl in school
column8: by offering to exercise with her to help her lose weight.  Patty insults her and rejects her offer.  Lara thinks to herself that Patty
column9: like all fat people
column10: is just too lazy to make any effort to lose the weight.  Soon after homecoming
column11: something awful begins to happen to Lara.  She starts to gain weight.  At first it's just a few pounds she thinks she can diet and exercise off.  But then it's more and more.  The more Lara diets and exercises
column12: the more weight she gains.  Her mother and father don't believe she is trying to lose the weight.  Her father tells her she needs to have more willpower
column13: and he stops calling her princess.  Lara's popularity is disappearing fast
column14: and she can't do anything about it.  How will she adjust to her new life as a fat girl?  I liked the honest treatment of Lara toward the end of the book
column15: when she has gained a bunch of weight.  The author didn't romanticize or try to make it seem like things were still the same for Lara.  Her entire life and all of her happiness was wrapped up in being pretty
column16: so it was reasonable to me that she would struggle a great deal to redefine herself.  Although I didn't like the character of Lara
column17: I thought the way she reacted was the way most teens in her situation would.  Just because she gained weight
column18: it wouldn't necessarily mean she equated herself with others who were overweight.  A prejudice as deep as hers and as accepted in society as hers
column19: would take a great deal of time to dissipate.  It would have seemed unrealistic to me if Lara's perceptions of beauty and worth were radically changed by the end of the book.

column1: If I had to recommend one book that best explains today's current events
column2: I wholeheartedly endorse Dave Hunt's book
column3: "Judgment Day."  I haven't agreed 100 percent with Mr. Hunt over the years and sometimes his writings are tough to understand.    This time I am very impressed.  His writing is clear and concise and he provides irrefutable references for his assertions.  What is especially strong is the array of issues that Hunt weaves into a cohesive theme that proves God is very angry with the world for their mistreatment of the Jews.  Soon He will return not as a suffering savior as He did nearly 2
column4: 000 years ago but as a conquering King to rescue the Jews from those who have sought their extermination.   Hunt addresses the rise of Islam and the complete absurdity of the political correctness that proclaims Islam is a religion of peace.  The media and the U.N. refuse to acknowledge that the Palestinian people didn't exist until 50 years ago and that they are pawns to exploit by their fellow Muslims.  The world also forgets history that the Jews were given far more land after World War I than the currently have.  Hunt makes the case that the land is no longer the issue:  If the Jews had one square mile in the Middle East
column5: Islam would want it and see the Jews pushed into the Mediterrean.    Most damning to Islam is that Hunt clearly shows how true Islam is violent and that Muhammad himself spread his religion by the sword.  Hunt demonstrates how poorly Islam treats their women and children.  (Where are the National Organization of Women and Hillary Clinton in ever denouncing Islam for this?)   Two excellent chapters are worth describing.  Chapter 9 describes the parallel between Nazi Germany with Czechsolovakia (1938) and the PLO (today) in painting public opinion and twisting the true story about their land grabbing.  The media conveniently ignores history's lessons about Hitler.  Both Hitler and Arafat were empowered by demons with a lust for killing Jews.   The other notable chapter is Chapter 12 which describes how most of today's churches are very anti-Israel
column6: even if they don't recognize it.  This view called "Replacement Theology" ignores numerous biblical passages that proclaim God is not done with the Jewish people.  Israel has been back in her land since 1948 for a very specific reason:  God's timeline is being set for the return of Jesus Christ to rescue a remnant of the Jews at the Battle of Armageddon.  Too many churches ignore Romans Chapter 11 that the New Testament church is a wild branch grafted into the natural branch (Israel) of the olive tree.  Gentiles are far too arrogant in self-importance and thinking that Israel has been disinherited from God's blessings.  We have forgotten our Jewish roots and God is far from being done with Israel... her very existence as a nation today is the largest sign for this generation to know that Jesus' return is soon to occur.    Lest anyone say that Dave Hunt does not love the Muslim
column7: that is simply not true.  At the end of the book
column8: he clearly and lovingly presents the gospel to the Muslim that the God of the bible is not Allah.  He shows that God's son died to redeem all who claim His shed blood as the payment for our sins.  That is the positive message from Judgment Day.

column1: This film is easily in the Top 5 of Fritz Lang's best films
column2: and quite possibly his #1 best sound film as well.  In addition to being Lang's debut sound film
column3: it was also Germany's very first sound film
column4: and really goes to show the benefits of having waited a little while to move away from silents and into sound pictures.  Almost every sound film from the late Twenties and very early Thirties suffers from a static camera and almost nonstop chatter
column5: as though film-making just went backwards in time by about 30 years and reverted back to being filmed stage plays instead of true "motion pictures."  But by 1931
column6: a number of those wrinkles had been ironed out
column7: and what resulted is an absolute masterpiece.  And unlike a number of directors working in those very early years of sound
column8: Lang struck a very good balance between dialogue scenes and scenes of relative silence.  He knew that the actors didn't have to be talking nonstop for it to be a good film worth watching.  Of course
column9: the director is only one part of the film's genius; the actors are brilliant too
column10: in particular Peter Lorre
column11: who truly gave the performance of his career even though it was his first starring role.  The film also really sets the stage for the later film noir genre
column12: what with the terrific shadows
column13: lighting
column14: and suspenseful mood and atmosphere.  The film does start out a little slowly
column15: but before long it gets more and more intense and compelling.  The plot needs time to be established and for the viewer to be fully drawn into it.  Lang did suspense and crime thrillers so well
column16: and this film is no exception.  A child murderer is on the loose
column17: and with no answers in sight
column18: the townspeople become paranoid and bloodthirsty
column19: particularly when it comes to those whom they already know are criminals.  The people in the underworld suffer the most from all of these paranoid accusations
column20: and so resent how their community is suffering that they resolve to not only find the murderer themselves
column21: but to do it all without any help from the police
column22: who in turn have no idea what these criminals are up to.  Even criminals have standards; it's often said that child rapists and murderers are reviled by "ordinary" criminals because that goes far beyond the pale of the things they did.  When the criminals finally track down Hans Beckert
column23: the murderer
column24: at a warehouse
column25: they tie up the night watchmen so they won't alert the police
column26: so insistent are they on capturing him by themselves
column27: even as they race to find him and get everyone back out before the police might get there.  The final section of the film
column28: in the criminals' kangaroo court
column29: is one of the most powerful scenes ever set to film.  One starts out feeling repugnance at this menace
column30: this person who molests and kills children
column31: but by the time the film is up
column32: one can't help but feel sorry for him
column33: or at least see him as a human being.  We never see him hurting children
column34: and don't even see his face right away.  He's not shown as a monster or an evil person; indeed
column35: who would ever suspect that such a baby-faced rotund man would be a child molester or murderer?  The treatment of him is surprisingly progressive for the era.  While what he's done isn't being excused or apologised for
column36: he's ultimately shown to be a victim himself
column37: a very sick man haunted by this monster inside of him
column38: doing these horrible horrible things because of it
column39: only finding peace when he's committing these criminal acts.  Is he any worse than these career criminals who have chosen to live this lifestyle
column40: people who could have become bank tellers
column41: teachers
column42: or doctors
column43: people who had a choice because they didn't have this monster constantly following them?  This must have been a positively revolutionary idea in 1931
column44: when many people blamed people like Beckert instead of considering that there might be medical or scientific reasons for it

column1: This book is the most important work on philosophy that I have seen in many years.  Taken together with their much earlier _Metaphors We Live By_ their treatment left very little to be desired.  If you have an interest in psychology of philosophy I would strongly recommend that you take the time to review those works.  The basic model that is presented in these books is further extended into the politcal realm in Lakoff's _Moral Politics
column2: and into the realm of mathematics in Lakoff and Nunez's _Where Mathematics Comes From_.  The incredible consistentency and workability of their arguments across all these subject areas really validates their basic premise and leaves the reader with a greater ability to understand themselves and other people in many different circumstances.  It's true as some other reviewers state that a portion of _Philosophy in the Flesh_ have appeared before their other works
column3: and that some of the principal ideas appear in a  different form from other writers like the existentialist Martin Heidigger but nowhere else have I ever seen such a comprehensive
column4: consistent and realistic view of the underlying conceptual processes that have produced Western Philosophy and how they ultimately resulted in serious errors that have been replicated again and again across the centuries

column1: "The Body of Jonah Boyd" begins in the late 60s and is narrated by Judith Denham
column2: known as 'Denny' to her friends. Denny is single
column3: and she works as a secretary for Dr. Ernest Wright
column4: a Psychology professor at Wellspring University in California. The fact that Denny is having an affair with Ernest doesn't really interfere with her friendship with Ernest's wife
column5: Nancy. Denny gradually becomes one of the "strays" invited to the Wrights' wonderful home every Thanksgiving. Denny
column6: as a wistful outsider
column7: makes the perfect narrator of the odd events that occur in the house on Thanksgiving on 1969. The Wrights are expecting Nancy's long-term friend
column8: Anne to visit with her new husband
column9: famous novelist Jonah Boyd. Nancy longs to see her old
column10: slightly estranged friend
column11: and see whether or not Anne has changed. Denny wants to meet Anne
column12: as she feels somewhat challenged by Nancy's much older--and supposedly deeper--friendship.  Anne has gone sadly downhill since Nancy last saw her. Glib
column13: slick Jonah Boyd attempts to cover the fact that their marriage is less than perfect
column14: but it's obvious to everyone that Anne is unhappy. She frets and sulks while Jonah entertains Denny and the Wrights by reading from his soon-to-be published novel. The Wright's precocious youngest son
column15: Ben is a would-be-poet
column16: and Jonah adopts a mentoring role while wooing various household members with his largesse. The only person to remain unimpressed is Anne. When Jonah's notebooks containing the only copy of his next novel
column17: go missing
column18: the household slides into an uproar. The mystery of the notebooks fractures many lives for decades to come.  "The Body of Jonah Boyd" is a brilliantly executed novel. Denny is the uninvolved narrator who is privy to the events of the fateful Thanksgiving
column19: and these events have powerful ramifications thirty years later. Author David Leavitt explores such complex issues as the creative process
column20: the writer's sacrifice for art
column21: guilt
column22: the balance of power within a marriage
column23: and family loyalty in just over two hundred pages of this marvelously woven tale. Leavitt's characters leap to life off the page
column24: and the story is both credible and satisfying--displacedhuman

 I'm so happy I took a chance and bought this item, it's exactly what I needed.   I bought the small/medium in black and it has a circumference of 23 3/4 Inches (60cm). The Headband is curved, at the widest point it is 3 inches and narrows to 2 1/4 inches. The width of 3 inches, is sufficient to completely cover my ears. It is only 3% Elastine, so there is a minimal stretch and it doesn't feel tight against my head, nor is it too loose to require constant adjusting. It sits comfortably, the polar fleece is what I would call a micro polar fleece - it has a small short pile and doesn't feel cheap.   I have worn this headband in temperatures as low as 15 Degrees Fahrenheit and it keeps my ears warm. Unlike earmuffs I can wear the headband indoors, it's one less Winter accessory that I have to remove whenever I step inside a building 
 If this is your first Suzanne Brockmann novel, STOP! The Troubleshooters" series is best read in sequence.  The characters are reappearing and their stories build through out the books.  Understanding the history of the storyline is most significant in "Gone Too Far" which explains the discrepancy in the previous reviews.   I always appreciate the characterization which Ms. Brockmann utilizes in her stories.  She is a superb story teller who teases her readers with bits and pieces of stories about old and new characters.  This makes her series a pleasure to read for those who have traveled with her along her journey... but can be frustrating and confusing to others who come in during the middle of things.   After reading the entire series in a frenzied month or two

column11: and as the 90's wore on they just kept getting wilder and crazier. John Q public was more apt to believe the tales of these boiler room or bucket shop brokers
column12: if you can call them that because half of them weren't even registered or licensed. The sad thing is
column13: in the 90's it was just as easy to build a legit book of business and make huge commissions the honest way. It's interesting and entertaining to re-visit the shenanigans of the last decade

column1: Twelve-year-old Veronica "Ronnie" Swan is used to babysitting her younger sisters while her parents are out running errands. Her family lives in a settlement in Utah too small to be called a town
column2: surrounded by members of the Mormon church to which they belong -- their life is a peaceful one
column3: a life of faith
column4: solitude
column5: and simplicity.  But a game of hide-and-seek while she's babysitting her sisters changes Ronnie's life forever.  The novel begins as Ronnie is called out from her hiding place by her sisters' strange silence
column6: only to find Becky and Ruthie lying on the ground beside the picnic table
column7: blood like "great dark pools of paint" gushing from their slashed throats.  Their killer -- later identified as Scott Early -- is sitting beside her sisters
column8: mumbling to himself
column9: still holding the scythe he used to kill them.    Scott Early is diagnosed with schizophrenia and is sentenced to spend three years in a mental hospital
column10: a verdict that Ronnie can't accept.  She is angry
column11: and she can't let go of the guilt she feels for being unable to save her sisters.  Just before Scott Early is released from the mental institution
column12: Ronnie's parents decide to offer him their forgiveness -- but Ronnie refuses to accompany them.  She can't forget what Scott Early did
column13: and she can't forgive him.    But her life will forever be intertwined with that of her sisters' killer.  Four years later
column14: when she has enough credits to graduate from high school
column15: she is drawn to San Diego
column16: where Scott Early lives with his wife and infant daughter. Ronnie begins taking classes to become an EMT
column17: and she convinces Scott Early's wife to hire her as a nanny for their daughter
column18: Juliet.  Once she has settled herself in the Earlys' life
column19: Ronnie beings to plan her revenge on her sisters' killer -- and you won't believe the results.  Talk about a roller-coaster of emotions:  CAGE OF STARS takes you through them all.  After the earth-shattering opening scene
column20: the reader is left feeling devastated and heartbroken and utterly involved in the Swans' grief.  And Mitchard keeps us there
column21: relentlessly
column22: by giving us a narrator so believable and sympathetic we can't help but be hooked.  Ronnie's voice is pure and childlike; her tone is conversational and forthright; her observations are are both simple and wise beyond her years.  Her innocence will break your heart.  And in addition to giving readers a brilliant heroine
column23: Mitchard also gives us a complicated
column24: sympathetic villain.  She brings us inside Scott Early's life
column25: makes us understand his illness -- and while we don't root for Scott Early
column26: we do pity him
column27: and
column28: unlike Ronnie
column29: we don't begrudge him his happiness or his family.  In CAGE OF STARS
column30: Mitchard has taken us inside the Mormon community
column31: a religion little-explored in contemporary fiction but much persecuted in the mainstream media.  She debunks lots of stereotypes about Mormons here
column32: as well as gives interesting information about their beliefs. A Mormon community (or any religious community
column33: for that matter) is the perfect place to set a story like CAGE OF STARS:  a story with forgiveness and redemption at its heart.  I tore through this book in a day; I just couldn't put it down.  And when I reached the perfectly-nuanced ending
column34: I couldn't help but shed a tear for the characters.  CAGE OF STARS is a powerful
column35: moving book about the nature of forgiveness
column36: and I'd definitely recommend it

Nonetheless there are many very enjoyable pieces in this very fine anthology.

column1: This is simply the best introduction to the fundamentals of economics ever written. The book is divided into two parts. Part one
column2: which takes all of four pages
column3: is the basic lesson of the title. Part two
column4: the remainder of the book
column5: consists of applications of that lesson to all types of economic issues. It clearly shows the folly of many modern economic policies
column6: including rent controls
column7: minimum wage laws
column8: government subsidies
column9: and protective tariffs.  Hazlitt is a great writer
column10: so much so that he somehow manages to make what is usually a dry
column11: unexciting subject fun to read. (A little-known fact: the philosopher Bertrand Russell liked Hazlitt's style so much that he wanted him to be his biographer - until
column12: that is
column13: Russell decided to write his life story himself.) As a result
column14: Hazlitt really succeeds in driving home his points. Economics has never been so interesting or so easy to understand.

column1: This is one of the best explanations of the Christian's responsibility to evangelize I have heard. This book isn't simply about predestination vs. free will
column2: it is a perspective on the whole question of Christian evangelism in light of God's sovereignty. Packer shows that
column3: when properly viewed
column4: the sovereignty of God does not remove our responsibility to evangelize. He writes a very good perspective on the relationship between God's sovereignty and man's responsibility
column5: showing that both the "freewill" position and the "hyper-Calvinist" (i.e. those who say that God's sovereignty precludes our responsibility to evangelize) position are wrong and unBiblical. He also makes some interesting comments on the WAY that we evangelize. For example
column6: he points out that many consider evangelistic sermons to be a "special" type of sermon and evangelistic meetings to be a "special" type of meeting
column7: but ALL of Scripture
column8: both Old and New  Testaments
column9: point to Jesus
column10: so any sermon that properly teaches the Bible is in a sense evangelistic
column11: and every properly run church service should point to Jesus. He points out that this attitude of "special" sermons and "special" meetings is very indicting of the modern church - i.e. that many "sermons" and "church services" are NOT really properly teaching the Bible and are NOT properly pointing to Jesus. This is particularly true of many topical sermons and "Christianity-lite" (I once heard of a Christmas "sermon" on "how to avoid anxiety at Christmastime" - no mention of Jesus' birth
column12: life
column13: teachings
column14: or work for us). This does not mean
column15: of course
column16: that we should not have special meetings or sermons for the sole purpose evangelism
column17: or that we should not make a special effort to evangelize. Packer argues that these should still occur
column18: particularly considering the paganism dominating our culture of late.  Anyone who wants to better understand the Christian's responsibility to evangelize
column19: or the relationship between God's sovereignty and man's evangelism (and who doesn't want to understand these better?)
column20: should read this book. It is excellent

column1: Unless you have never seen a college basketball game
column2: you probably know quite a bit about coach John Wooden and his success at UCLA.  Several excellent books have attempted to capture the essence of his coaching philosophy.  All of those books made you admire coach Wooden and want to emulate him.  But you ended up feeling like you were dealing with a saint who emerged full formed from a clam shell.  How could a mere mortal follow his foot steps?    Wooden on Leadership takes a revealing look at how that philosophy evolved
column3: the mistakes he made along the way
column4: how he corrected those mistakes and the regrets he has today.  A high point for me came from seeing his notes during the years that the philosophy evolved.    You still feel like you are dealing with a saint
column5: but a saint who (like Paul when he was Saul) started out with some imperfections that you may recognize in yourself.  I came to appreciate several dimensions of the Wooden philosophy that I hadn't understood before.  Here is my new learning:  1.  Focus on helping each player become the best they can be in contributing to the team
column6: and help the players understand how they can and are contributing to the team.    2.  Attract people with good values who are eager to improve in team contributions.  3.  Set a good example.  4.  There are no little things.  Everything is important.  I hope that anyone who ever coaches children's or school sports will read this book and be encouraged to become a better leader.    Even if you coach fencing
column7: you can learn a lot from this book

column1: A nice breath of fresh air
column2: this book focuses on the individual struggles of four fairly well-off dominican girls caught in between cultures
column3: as their lives carry them from the Dominican Republic
column4: to New York
column5: and back.     Unlike many U.S. latina authors
column6: Alvarez chooses not to focus on tired old cliches of inexorable racism or institutional opression as the only themes capable of producing a novel.   Instead
column7: she exposes the reader to the often complex inner world of  the young female attempting to recalibrate her identity in a new culture during the bumpy transition to adulthood.  Alvarez plays no favorites here: Old World traditions and empty American promises are equally ridiculed
column8: while the evolution of the poetic inner self becomes the novel's focal point.  The personal struggle is given precedence over the group struggle.  The realistic prose
column9: absence of excessive description
column10: and smooth sentence structure make it a fast and enjoyable read. The story
column11: written in "reverse" fashion
column12: begins at it's end
column13: and then works it's way backwards into the past.  Other than being a neat little narrative trick
column14: I doubt whether this adds much to the esthetic value of the novel.    Overall
column15: a nice contribution to the rapidly diversifying US latino literature canon.

This may be the most entertaining book of TV criticism since Harlan Ellison's legendary "The Glass Teat."  Tucker appreciates great art no matter where he finds it; he says that he needs to acknowledge that he has "been nourished as much by 'Buffy the Vampire Slayer' as the novels of Philip Roth." column1: Brian Hayes has produced an excellent book which descibes the workings of the industrial infrustructure as we see it on the surface of the industrialised world
column2: in particular the US and Italy.  Hayes clearly explains what we often see as mysterious
column3: arcane and inexplicable structures in the industrial landscape in clear terms
column4: without becoming tediously technical and using difficult technical terminology
column5: regarding those who may not be overly familar with the mechanics and procedures of mining
column6: energy production and other similar industries.  The text is profusely illustrated with clear colour photographs with captions on every page. Very few diagrams are included
column7: unless absolutely necessary. The captions associated with the photographs elucidate the workings of the machinery or structures depicted. Details such as pylon insulators are also explained. Importantly
column8: a sense of scale is always provided by pointing out an object in the picture which is recognisable.  This is an important book
column9: long needed. It is non-judgemental
column10: and written with a playfulness which makes it all the more engaging. The analogies and explanations given are clear
column11: and the language is accessible most readers including young people from the age of ten
column12: without being condescending.  Infrastructure is a well designed book
column13: produced on art paper (glossy and china coated)
column14: and is actually quite weighty. The layout is clear and functional
column15: good typography and eminently legible. The design matches its contents

column1: If you consider yourself a melodeath metal fan

column3: it is absolutely mandatory that you're familiar with the following four words: "Slaughter Of The Soul." If there ever was a classic in this genre

column1: The author has done a masterful job of building the case for a serious exploration of a bio-based energy economy. The book has a friendly not-too-technical style and it's incredibly well researched
column2: carefully documented and very well organized. As an added bonus
column3: Biodiesel starts off with an insightful forward by celebrated author and environmentalist
column4: Bill McKibben.    After setting the tone for the book by bringing to light the potential crisis of Peak Oil
column5: Pahl begins to delve into part of the solution as he leads the reader on a great story ride through the life (and death!) of Rudolf Diesel
column6: to the early pioneers of biodiesel across the European eco-industrial landscape and back to the present day biodiesel industry currently emerging in the U.S.. The book is full of personal interviews with key players that brings this rapidly evolving world of agriculture
column7: science and alternative energy to life. And Greg Pahl does an excellent job of providing a balanced look at both the possibilities and the social and environmental challenges of drawing increasing amounts of energy from the soil.  I've been pretty involved in sustainable development for years (and biofuels in particular) and I can only say that this latest book by the author is a real gift and a "must read" for anyone interested in or working towards a renewable energy future

column1: This is an important film. The writer's original intention was to craft a film loosley around The Sandpebbles and African Queen.  The Special Edition of this film includes writers' observations by Alex Lasker and Patrick Cirillo
column2: and they narrate as the film proceeds. They describe the evolution and changes to the original script
column3: subject to a studio seeking to craft a film which would create profits and be a good vehicle for Bruce Willis. But
column4: the writers wanted to draw attention to the state of Africa
column5: and the recurring problems resulting in horrible human rights violations. They bring awareness to genocide and civil war where the western world does not want to get involved.  Reading reviews
column6: it's amazing what this film has meant to people. Some see it as a great but mindless action film. It's meaningful enough to bring others to tears. I recently read a review proclaiming that liberals and "America hating" leftists would hate the film
column7: and that the film represents the goose-step of conservatives. This is certainly at odds with the writers' intentions. As a socially liberal and left leaning American (but fiscally conservative)
column8: this attitude left me puzzled. I've always seen conservative types as huddled around their little pile of stuff acquired through life like golems
column9: and concerned with little else in this world. They just want to protect their little pile. A good American to them has a responsibility to care little for the rest of the world
column10: unless we can plunder someone to fatten the coffers. Neoconservatives feel a requirement to democratize the world
column11: as planned out in the imperialistic Project For A New Century. Conservative administrations believe that war is good for corporations and business
column12: but place no emphasis on human rights. Create a war and watch the stock market go crazy. It doesn't matter that our children will be left to figure out the unfathomable debt. Frankly
column13: I don't get it. "Liberals and leftists" believe in international responsibility
column14: and that's what this film is about.  Bruce Willis plays a good soldier who is siezed by conscience in the film
column15: and finds it necessary break his orders to accomplish the "right thing". I've read reviews condemning this action
column16: stating that orders must never be broken
column17: and that in real life Willis would have been rightfully destined for punishment. The military order transcends moraltiy and ethics. In the real world this fact is probably true
column18: so perhaps the film is a bit of a fantasy.  This movie is important because it draws attention to a state of affairs in Africa from which most Americans have been insulated. Recently
column19: The Sudanese government's systematic murder and starvation of black Sudanese has been in the news
column20: thanks to George Clooney and others. It also draws attention toward America's view of the rest of the world.  I found this movie thought provoking as well as being an exciting adventure story. Hopefully people will see this and ask some important questions. While the great nation of America should not be the world's police force
column21: we should be a rock solid moral example for the rest of the world. Want to talk about power? What better power than that which is born out of respect. Instead we have been on a morally questionable path
column22: conducting an unneccesary war
column23: spending trillions and inflicting pain and suffering. We have lost 2500 soldiers of our own
column24: with thousands wounded and traumatized. And for what? Oil? Other countries natural resources? 9/11 hysteria? A neoconservative agenda?  Oil
column25: natural resources and greed are one of the major contributions to events of genocide around the world. This is a sub-theme of the film
column26: intimating that America would have no intention of involvement for humanitarian issues
column27: but oil is another matter. It's sad but true. We have a choice in who we elect
column28: and where they are destined to lead us. We still have elected officials who regret that the south lost the Civil War
column29: and regret the civil rights advances since then. They would consider anyone a leftist who would champion civil rights and who would sympathize with the genocide themes in the film.  This is what the film meant to me. My "liberals eye view" found it deeply moving and morally uplifting. One more thing ... in Special Features is a feature called "Voices of Africa". Eight African actors in the film recount their personal experiences and horrors in the Sudan
column30: Nigerian
column31: Congo
column32: Sierra Leone
column33: and Liberia. Thankfully many of them found refuge
column34: and a chance for a future by escaping to America. These moving interviews alone are reason enough to purchase the Special Edition.  When it's time
column35: vote for an administration who will make this country proud. See this film as a reminder that we are each our brother's keeper

column1: There are very few books about the theory of game design.   Most of the books which purport to be about game design theory have titles like _Game Design: Theory and Practice_ [Richard Rouse III: 2001]
column2: and focus much more on the latter than the former
column3: usually in the context of commercial computer games.  The exceptions to this rule generally approach the subject of game design theory from a particular perspective
column4: e.g.
column5: as a communication method or "future's language." [Duke: 1974]  So when _Rules of Play: Game Design Fundamentals_ (by Katie Salen and Eric Zimmerman) was published by MIT Press in 2004
column6: I took immediate interest.  The book largely lived up to expectations.  Weighing in at a hefty 672 pages of relatively small type
column7: this textbook-format tome is
column8: as the title might suggest
column9: heavy on game design theory but light on practice.  This makes it a excellent complement to the established game design literature.  Structurally
column10: the book is fairly straightforward and is divided into four major sections: Core Concepts
column11: Rules
column12: Play
column13: and Culture
column14: each of which is capped by an essay or a game design by an established game designer written especially for this volume.  The first section (together with two brief chapters preceeding it) discusses necessary background ideas
column15: defining important terms and presenting concepts to be built upon later.  Besides preparing the reader for the next  500 pages
column16: it's in this section that the authors accomplish one of their primary goals of the book: creating a game design vocabulary.   Creating such a critical vocabulary
column17: they argue
column18: is an important step towards treating game design as a discipline
column19: because you need such a tool to education game designers
column20: to pass skills and knowledge from one generation of designers to another
column21: to faciliate audience-building by enabling critical discussion of games
column22: and finally as a buffer against criticism
column23: by giving "us" -- a word which takes on new meaning in the last third of the book
column24: when they discuss the various ways players become de facto game designers -- the vocabulary and understanding to defend gaming as an activity from those who would censor it.  These points are borrowed from an essay by Henry Jenkins
column25: a media theorist and game scholar who is also the head of the Comparative Media Studies program at MIT.  (As a quick sidebar
column26: this book may be worth buying for the bibliography alone.)  Of course
column27: vocabulary is only the start of an effort to establish a "critical discourse for game design."  Or
column28: as  Salen and Zimmerman explain
column29: "a critical vocabulary lets us talk to each other."  The last three sections of the book form the beginnings of that critical discourse.  Each of these sections highlights a specific primary schema ("a conceptual lens we can apply to the analysis or creation of a game")
column30: with most of the chapters in these sections focusing on related lower-level schemas.  For example
column31: in the section on the schema "Games as Play
column32: there is a chapter on Games as Narrative Play
column33: which examines both narrative elements of games and narrative as a result of game play.  These schema-based chapters borrow heavily from a wide variety of disciplines, and it is through these schemas that major insights regarding game design can be found.  (For instance, the chapter on Games as the Play of Pleasure" has an interesting discussion of the importance of short-term goals
column34: which serve both to help players make plans in a game
column35: and also provide moments of satisfaction when these goals are reached.)  A lot of these insights will not be new to experienced game designers
column36: but what is new is the systematic framework in which the insight is embedded.  Or
column37: more correctly
column38: frameworks.  I would argue that this multiple-perspective approach is the book's primary strength.  Rather than taking a given theoretical construct and forcing all of "games" into it
column39: it starts with a few core concepts and then generates a plethora of interrelated-but-distinct models with which to examine any game.  Any given model may or may not be suited to an individual game -- or
column40: perhaps more accurately
column41: may or may not have the potential to produce new insights -- but as a whole they are a powerful collection of tools.  If you have a hammer
column42: the old saying goes
column43: everything looks like a nail.  In this case
column44: Salen and Zimmerman have handed the reader a fairly complete toolbox.  (Note that I will admit to shoehorning this analogy into place just a little bit.  A hammer is construction tool
column45: not an analysis tool; it's job is on the *practical end*
column46: not the theoretical.  A better analogy would be a toolbox that contains an MRI machine
column47: a spectrograph
column48: an x-ray machine
column49: a CAT scanner
column50: and a simple camera
column51: but I don't know of any old sayings that use those particular tools.)  This comprehensive approach draws on a wide variety of disciplines
column52: from pyschology and literature to software engineering.  Within the field of games it casts an equally wide net
column53: drawing examples from computer games
column54: parlor games
column55: Live Action Roleplaying Games
column56: boardgames
column57: professional sports
column58: schoolyard games
column59: and others.  It's not unusual for one paragraph to discuss a game like Chutes and Ladders
column60: the next to discuss professional basketball
column61: and a third to discuss Quake.  Such a diverse treatment of the subject guarantees that there is always an example available for a type of game the reader is familar with
column62: even if the inevitable result is a little bit of shoehorning of examples.  (I remain unconvinced
column64: that Tic Tac Toe is really a "territorial acquisition" game.)  There are also plenty of new games to learn about  -- for instance
column65: did you know that someone ran a live action PacMan game in New York City? This comprehensiveness extends to the bibliography and footnotes.  Another strength derives directly from one of the goals of the book: the authors are attempting to create a vocabulary.  As a result
column66: they are meticulous about defining terms
column67: especially when they are borrowing concepts from other disciplines.  This can occasionally be a little tiresome
column68: but in the end it's always worth the effort.  The weaknesses of the book are in many ways mirror images of the strengths -- it's occasionally too theoretical
column70: and too multi-disciplinary.  It tends to wordiness
column71: and occasionally the authors seem to base significant points on what one could argue is a word game
column73: they draw upon the definition of play as in "loose" ("too much play in the fan belt") when defining the idea of "playing a game" or "game as a form of play."  It's a clever little example of creative pseudo-etymology
column74: but I'm not sure that I buy the construct
column75: even if it does seem to offer insight on occasion.  (Note that I originally wrote "play on words" rather than "word game.")  One glaring void in this comprehensive approach
column77: is that the book doesn't really focus on games that are played for reasons other than the pleasure of the participants.  Professional military games are mentioned only in passing
column78: large seminar games not at all
column79: and it's probably safe to say that when one thinks of DOD gaming
column80: such concepts as "Games as Cultural Resistance" (chapter 32) are probably not the sort of idea that comes to mind.  Indeed
column81: much of the sections on "Play" and "Culture" might seem to be inapplicable to the type of gaming sponsored by DOD
column82: because they do not address the unique reasons as to why military organizations participate in the creation and playing of games.  I think that conclusion would be a mistake.  The motivation as to why individuals play DOD games is certainly different than the motivation of your average _Vampire: The Masqerade_ player
column83: but the mechanisms by which a player finds the experience meaningful probably isn't.  A bored or alienated player is bored or alienated
column84: regardless of whether he's playing in the latest first-person shooter on his own initiative or Millenium Challenge because he was told to be there. If anything
column85: these issues might be more important in a military games context: Joe Civilian Gamer can simply stop playing DOOM if he gets bored
column86: but gamers that are forced into situations they don't want to be in have a tendency to cease their willing suspension of disbelief ("step outside the magic circle
column87:
as Salen and Zimmerman would say) and cause problems for others as well.  So, in short, I think the book is worth the time and the price tag ($50 list), both for game designers in general and professional military game designers in particular

 Subbing at an elementary library earlier this month I came across this marvelous book on the shelving cart. I bet it is not on the shelf very often.  Kids love books about their favorite animals. Books on dog and cat breeds fly off the shelves. Put a puppy on the cover and there is instant interest.  Veterinary medicine is a career that is intriguing to many children. The photography shines in this book and invites the reader into a state of the art emergency care facility. There are photos of surgery that are detailed but not gruesome. The images of animals being cushioned with pillows and blankets are particularly comforting to young pet owners. Kind and caring professionals offer insight into their work at the ER.  The book also deals with the loss of a pet. Lucy is a ball python who escaped from her bag and got behind the dash of her owner's car. Despite the vet's attempts to revive the snake Lucy dies from hypothermia. Her owner describes his feelings of sadness and loss.  There are interesting insets, including abbreviations and terminology the doctors use (example HBC is hit by car) and human foods that are dangerous to animals.  State reading assessments use nonfiction selections to test student reading ability. This would be an excellent choice to model nonfiction reading. Young readers will also pick this one up and pore over every word on their own

 My only complaint with this wonderful book is that it doesn't touch on childhood vaccinations. This is an important topic in natural healing and the word vaccination isn't even mentioned in the index. Since this book was written in 1998, perhaps the chickenpox vaccine was still very new and the measles vaccine was very commonly used. I understand that one book can't cover all topics, but this is a big one. I would think parents who are looking for natural alternatives to health and healing would like to at least question their options when considering when and whether to vaccinate their children. There is an entire chapter dedicated to treating chicken pox and herpes, but nothing on measles. Neither vacccination will I give to my 11-month-old son and I am always looking for more information on the topic.   Although the book isn't loaded with complex medical terms, it isn't shy on information. It is written for the layman (with occasional pictures and tips boxes), and provides a well-rounded approach to diagnosing and gently treating COMMON illnesses in children. At the same time, the authors were careful to encourage traditional medical advice when appropriate
