column1: This review is dedicated to my father. Along with "Midsummer Night's Dream" and "Macbeth
column2: The Tempest" was one of my father's favorite plays. This play begins with an unfortunate ship caught in a storm. In the next scene
column3: we move from the ocean to a nearby island. There we learn that the tempest was not from natuaral causes
column4: but from the magic of our hero Prospero. Prospero has a grudge against certain members of the ship. Prospero tells his daughter Miranda the story of his past. (Miranda must be in her late teens at least
column5: but she often sounds a lot younger. Quite possibly due to the fact that she has lead such a sheltered life.) His brother Antonio usurped his dukedom and handed control over to King Alonso. Prospero and his daughter were banished
column6: and the benevolent Gonzalo furnished Prospero with books he loved. Prospero has been called the greatest representation of Shakespeare himself. We may also note that while Prospero is the hero of this play
column7: he does have one notable fault. He does enjoy playing God. One example is when his fairy servant Ariel begs the promised 'freedom of air.' Rather than asking politely for just a little extra time
column8: (which is certainly not unheard of between friends)
column9: Prospero reminds Ariel that he rescued Ariel from imprisonment by Sycorax and he threatens Ariel with consequences if Ariel brings up the matter again before it is time. Moving on
column10: we meet the deceased Sycorax's remaining son Caliban. Prospero tried to be nice to Caliban
column11: but Caliban crossed the line by trying to rape his daughter Miranda. (Again
column12: Prospero plays God. Rather than using his magic to destroy Caliban
column13: he keeps him alive and makes Caliban perform services that he finds disagreeable. 'Disgrace is more painful than death.') We later meet Ferdinand. (The son of the King on the ship.) He sees Miranda and loves her. Prospero feels he can not let his daughter be won too easily
column14: and like Caliban
column15: Ferdinand is subjected to manual labor. Onto Act 2. The crew of the boat from 1.1 has survived and made it to the island.  Shakespeare uses an interesting technique here. Through Prospero's passages
column16: we see the king as his enemy. But we are allowed generous sympathy for him when he is struck with sorrow over his missing son. And even Ariel (Prospero's loyal servant) thwarts an attempt by Anotnio and Sebastian to kill the king. Caliban then meets Stephano and Trinculo. The three become friends (through the comical use of some wine) and join together to defeat Prospero and take over the island. Onto Act 3. Ferdinand and Miranda express their love for each other
column17: and Prospero (watching from an unseen location) is pleased. Anotnio and Sebastian make another plan to kill Alonso. At this point
column18: we can infer that Ariel has warned Prospero of the Caliban/Stephano/Triculo conspiracy. But Prospero sees yet another chance to play God. Antonio
column19: Sebastian
column20: Alonso
column21: and Gonzalo are starving. So Prospero and Ariel create an image of banquet long enough to tantalize them before they make it vanish. (Some people may find this funny
column22: but it is somewhat below the belt
column23: and it does prove my point that Prospero likes playing God.) Onto Act 4. Prospero shows his gentler side when he tells Ferdinand that he consents to the marriage of Miranda to him. (Like a reasonable father
column24: he asks that Ferdinand 'wait' until the marriage is performed.) In a beautiful "Midsummer Night's Dream" nostalgia moment
column25: there is a dance of fairies. One interesting thing we notice here is yet another reason why Miranda sounds a lot younger than she is. (She must be in her late teens. But as I said before
column26: she sounds much younger. A little too sweet and innocent. Well
column27: Prospero does NOT confide in her. Prospero DID not tell her of the conspiracy against him.  One reason may be that Prospero who likes playing God thought the attempt on his life was laughable. It may also be that Prospero realizes that the concept of a conspiracy against his life would be beyond the scope of this gentle and kind but too sheltered Miranda. Recall
column28: Miranda was still an infant in exile.) Moving on
column29: Prospero gives the famous and beautiful passage: 'Our revels now have ended.' It is tempting to believe that Shakespeare is getting ready to say farewell to his art seeing that "The Tempest" was his 2nd last play. Well
column30: the joy of the moment is broken as Prospero realizes his enemies are still out there. In 5.1
column31: Prospero gives yet another beautiful passage on his accomplishments. And with the help of Ariel
column32: Prospero realizes that revenge is not a virtue. (Rather forgiveness is. Interesting that someone who enjoyed playing God finally realizes that forgiveness is the true merit of a God.) Well
column33: Prospero reconciles with the King
column34: Antonio
column35: and Sebastian and forgives them. Soon afterwards Prospero informs the king that his son Ferdinand is safe and happily getting ready to marry Miranda. Even Caliban
column36: Stephano
column37: and Trinculo are forgiven. The play ends in utter happiness. Some people like to think that Prospero 'breaking his staff' is an indication that Shakespeare will write no more. But as Isaac Asimov said: "This is too sentimental...a compulsive writer like Shakespeare could not deliberately plan to give up writing while he was still capable of holding a pen." And in support of Isaac Asimov
column38: Shakespeare did afterwards write "Henry VIII" as well as parts of "The Two Noble Kinsmen."

column1: Mikhail Bakhtin first began "Rabelais and His World" in 1917 during the heady days of the Russian Revolution. Like some of the colleges of today
column2: the University of St. Petersburg at the height of the Revolution boasted a flexible curriculum and encouraged free thought among its students. While the gunfire echoed in the streets
column3: Bakhtin and his colleagues gathered to declare the Russian Revolution the "Third Renaissance". This comparison between the Italian Renaissance and the Russian Revolution inspired him to begin his dissertation on Rabelais. The events of the Revolution swept everyone up into the societal transitions. No one could just be a bystander. From this all-encompassing mood of social interaction arose Bakhtin's concept of the "theater without footlights". As for the significance of the individual in the Carnivalesque one has only to look to the Fool. Bakhtin considered his first reading of Friedrich Nietzsche an epiphany. The great German philosopher remained one of Bakhtin's most important influences throughout his writing career. The Fool
column4: as an extension of the carnival
column5: is the ultimate Nietzschean character. Able to move between worlds
column6: he demonstrates the power of the individual to transcend societal norms. Bakhtin states
column7: "the images of folk culture are absolutely fearless and communicate this fearlessness to all". The Fool is representative of this utopian ideal personified in the individual

 Plot: In a revoltion by the village against his father/the King, Enion -- the young Prince and apprentice of knight Bowen (Dennis Quaid) -- is injured. As the injury could be fatal, the Queen rushes him to a dragon with the request of it's healing power. To do so, the dragon must give half of his heart to the Prince (and, of course, he does). Yet once Enion bcomes King, he disregards any teachings of the Old Code from Bowen and becomes a cruel and corrupt young man, bringing only choas to his time of reign. From here, feeling that the dragon is the reason for Enion's rebellion, Bowen vows to slay every single dragon left in existence. But once he comes upon the last dragon left (Sean Connery with vocal duties only, as the dragon is CGI), he finds him impossible to defeat. They resort to friendship instead, and Bowen gives the dragon a name: Draco (after the constellation). They team up, traveling village to village, having Bowen to pretend he slays an evil dragon (Draco) that is inhabiting whichever current village they are working (this humorous scam being done for money, of course). But soon, the past catches up to both of them and they run into the old village now cruelly run by Enion. They, with the assistance of the villagers, decide to over-run Enion and his small army. With the help of Draco, it seems possible. But Enion ends up capturing Draco. Bowen must kill Enion and save Draco, but discovers a connection between the two that makes such a task much more difficult than he'd imagined. I've given most of the plot here, but I won't say too much about this part, because it is indeed the center of the climatic drama. All I can say is that Bowen must choose between two very difficult decisions!  Dragonheart succeeds in not only a humorous and fantastic movie, but also a heart-warming one. The ending (supported by the wonderful score) brought tears to my eyes, and the story is one that will stick with any viewer for quite some time. Although the CGI dragon is a turn-off to some, be assured that for the effects available at the time, these guys used the best. Also, as for the DVD, there are some great special features including inside looks at Draco, the effects, the story, etc. This is an adventure/fantasy film perfect for almost any age and I would certainly recommend at least a rental. If you're into dragons or just fantasy in general, Dragonheart is a must-see!         
 The sound quality of the Ultra-Lounge series is excellent, even though the songs were recorded mostly in the 50's and 60's. Capitol Records packs each CD with carefully chosen tracks consistent with the theme of the particular volume in the series. Many of the selections that appear here aren't available elsewhere, either because the original album on which the song appeared is out of print, or because the song was issued as a single and never collected in an album. A few 'previously unreleased' tracks also appear here. This series is a wonderful introduction to the music of a by-gone era, and each album includes detailed notes on each track (artist, writers, date recorded, how released, etc.). I heartily recommend it to anyone who has an interest in this type of music

'Red Elephant' feels like a cold bath with taunting guitar and aching vocals but delivers a positive tone. '5/4' is my favorite song on the album with it's swaying guitar and tender vocals. 'Waffle's agitated progress fires on all cylinders straight to the heart. '8' and 'J'Nuh' are respectively grand in a gentle nerve splitting tempo that elevate the album into greatness 
 Rob Huizenga's account of his time as medical intern for the Los Angeles Raiders provides a provocative behind-the-scenes look at the reality of NFL football that is by turns hysterically funny and deeply disturbing. He  conveys both the perverse attraction of being part of a team camped out at  the edge of reality"
column12: and also the shocked disbelief at the suspect and  highly dangerous extremes that football players will go to in order to play  while injured and so preserve their job. As team intern from 1983 to 1990
column13: Huizenga faced a unique dilemma: his concern as a responsible doctor for  his patients
column14: the players
column15: continually conflicted with their own desire to  play through potentially crippling injuries. His frequent confrontations as  well with team owner Al Davis over the treatment of players clearly  illustrates why Davis's obsessive "win at all costs" attitude has made he  and his team NFL pariahs. More generally
column16: Huizenga pointedly shows how the  intense pressure upon players from team
column17: fans and the league itself
column18: to  consistently perform at the highest possible level drives individuals to  abuse themselves and their bodies with a myriad of chemical substances. For  Raider and non-Raider fans alike
column19: Huizenga's book makes for compulsive  reading. His experiences highlight the extreme "otherness" of NFL football
column20: in which lies its principle attraction - the oddball characters who play  it
column21: the unorthodox means they endure to keep playing
column22: and the high mental  and physical cost that they pay for success in such a ferocious game

column1: There is no writer I know of who is more adept at capturing the depth and intricacies of a given human emotion than Gabriel Garcia Marquez. He never tires of exploring the depths of love and never ceases to be fascinating in so doing.  In 'Love in the Time of Cholera'
column2: Garcia Marquez tells the tale of Florentino Ariza and his boundless
column3: but unfulfilled love for a childhood sweetheart named Fermina Daza. The longing and torment that Florentino experiences throughout over half a century of Fermina Daza's marriage is at times excruciating. However it is still lent a certain tragic and poignant beauty by the author.  The emotions and anguish that Florentino suffers are surely ones that are common to any human being. Equally anyone who has experienced these emotions
column4: will know that their complexity and depth easily necessitate the 400+ pages that comprise this book. Also that it would take a writer like Gabriel Garcia Marquez to do them justice.  The conclusion of this novel is
column5: ultimately
column6: realistic. The conclusion of an unrequited love is rarely straightforward. There is usually not a clean
column7: Hollywood-esque finish and the novel perfectly conveys this. Without being even the slightest bit populist
column8: this novel is a beautifully thought out and beautifully rendered work
column9: which will surely resonate with all of its readers

It was "D.I.Y." that introduced me to the solo work of Peter Gabriel. (The first one had been under my radar
column2: a mistake soon corrected.) I knew Gabriel's work with Genesis and while I liked the band I didn't need to have it all. But then this song came out. I can still remember hearing it on the now defunct FM station WIOQ
column3: sitting in my car and thinking
column4: "Wow
column5: I've got to get that." The line
column6: "When things get so big you can't trust them at all; if you want some control you've got to keep it small
column7: really spoke to me ; no doubt helped by the passion and anxiety in Gabriel's voice. When I listened to the whole album, I discovered an artist still trying to find his way to the world rhythms that he made his own. On this recording, Gabriel is still playing around with Genesis style characters and imagery here; on songs like On the Air" with its hermit DJ and "Animal Magic's Professional
column8: Gabriel revisits some older themes of separation and distance from the norm. But on songs like D.I.Y." and "Indigo" you start to see the shell cracking as Gabriel touches on some personal spaces that always seemed to be held at arm's length before. Some songs are a bit too buried in Robert Fripp's production (Particularly "Home Sweet Home" which would have been better served by a starker setting.) but overall there is an emotional feeling here that serves as a harbinger of Gabriel's later work.

column1: Fifty-three years old Harry Barnett accompanies his much younger and obviously healthier guest visiting English schoolteacher Heather Mallender on a tour of the Greek Isle Rhodes where he has lived for about nine years as a housesitter.  He stopped for a smoke and a second wind while she went on
column2: but after waiting for a while for Heather to return
column3: Harry anxiously sets off to find her.  Instead he sees four stripes of "cerise and silver" from Heather's scarf caught on a low hanging tree branch.  He reports her missing to the authorities who suspect he killed her.  Harry quickly realizes that the cops assume he harmed Heather.  Deciding he needs to prove otherwise and finding nothing useful on Rhodes
column4: Harry traces Heather back to England He learns Heather was visiting a psychiatrist
column5: helping her not very successfully cope with the loss of her sister to an IRA bomb.  However
column6: Harry soon finds his own past not that of Heather's is where the answer lies
column7: but obtaining the proof could prove deadly from people he trusts.  On the surface the story line is a simplistic amateur sleuth investigation starring a dissolute loser hiding from his roots.  However
column8: that would oversimplify a complex somewhat convoluted thriller filed with twists and plenty of irony as the reluctant warrior returns to the place of his greatest failure amidst other fiascos.  The story line grips the reader from the moment Harry panics when he realizes that somehow Heather is missing and continues to hold reader attention as the "hero's" stomach churns when he concludes he is the only suspect and never let's go until Harry's final sardonic confrontation with a foe PAINTING THE DARKNESS with deception and blackmail.  Harriet Klausner

column1: I've read many political books - mostly conservative.  Michael Savage
column2: Sean Hannity
column3: and Bill O'Reilly are just a few of the authors whose books I have read
column4: and while I agree with most of the opinions they expressed
column5: I found the content to be rather dry and mundane.  Don't get me wrong
column6: I still liked them.  Michael Savage stands out among other talk show hosts like Bill O'Reilly and Sean Hannity who pump out the blandest political books on the market
column7: as his writing actually appears to have involved some labor.  But not until I read Al Franken's "The Truth" did I realize how colorful and entertaining political non-fiction can be.  Now
column8: whether the views expressed in Franken's books can qualify as "non-fiction" is up to you
column9: but regardless
column10: I found this book to be the single most funny and amusing political book I have ever read.  Not only is the satire in "Truth" razor-sharp
column11: but the overall "flow" is just magnificent.  Beginning with a dramatic memoir of the '04 election and sailing smoothly through the remainder of the book with Franken's charming humor and eloquent dissection of The Issues
column12: "The Truth" reads like an ocean wave brushing against the sand.  And I stress this particularly with THIS BOOK
column13: as I have just recently read "Lies" and
column14: though wonderfully entertaining
column15: it does not flow from chapter to chapter so seamlessly as its successor.    Franken has a gift
column16: and it ain't for political analysis; it's for the written word.  If I weren't so smart
column17: I'd consider him terribly persuasive
column18: and that's definitely a talent unto its own.  Obviously
column19: I find this book's weakness to be the opinions which the amazing writing carries
column20: and so the 4 stars.  One of the biggest problems with Franken
column21: and every other not-so-radical liberal I've examined
column22: is he is not willing to accept the downfalls of his extremist counterparts
column23: if he is even aware of them at all.  Something you'll notice about liberals is they are much more about bashing the Right than actually giving their opinion.  (Okay
column24: they'll give their opinion on global warming and health care - things that
column25: no matter how insensitive this sounds
column26: are MEANINGLESS in a world where people are currently fighting to destroy the West as we know it.)  Instead of challenging the actual DOCTRINE of the social-conservative agenda
column27: Franken zeros in on meaningless hypocricies amongst members of the right wing like Rush Limbaugh and Bill O'Reilly - people I have no respect for - as if their mistakes disqualify the actual motives of present-day conservatism
column28: or represent the others of the right wing who don't wish to be represented by such morons.  Now true
column29: the Right bashes the Left just as the Left bashes the Right
column30: but there's still an urgency in the right wing to solve the global terrorism crisis that is just not apparent in the left wing.  This is why Air America has failed:  Franken can get away with his twisting of the truth through writing
column31: for the art of the literature itself distracts from the utter rubbish of it's ideological base
column32: but when you must go on the radio every day with nothing more to say than "Rush Limbaugh is a pig
column33: you're going to fall flat on your face.  In the end, The Truth" is so well-written and so entertaining
column34: yet so politically misguided.  I love it
column35: but not for the reasons Franken might want me to.  Oh well.  It's a masterpiece

column1: This is a low-fi recording of a sound collage event that took place in Los Angeles in 1965.  A bunch of pre-recorded tapes were triggered and overlaid in real time using chance operations.  This CD contains excerpts from the six hour performance.    Cage was sincere about process over product.  He reportedly didn't listen to records (of his own music or anybody else's).  I think this CD is fun
column2: but since there's no intentionality to the sound constructions it's hard to grade.  I think the last two tracks are the best blend of the source material (the same tapes keep popping up in different tracks) but if you appreciate media collage you'll enjoy the whole thing.  Be warned
column3: though
column4: that this is not "soundboard" quality -- sounds more like somebody set a tape recorder in the middle of the room

column1: The financial performance of an organization is essential for its success. Even non-profit organizations must deal in a sensible way with funds they receive.  In 1992
column2: an article by Robert Kaplan and David Norton entitled "The Balanced Scorecard - Measures that Drive Performance" in the Harvard Business Review caused a lot of attention for their method
column3: and led to their business bestseller
column4: "The Balanced Scorecard: Translating Strategy into Action"
column5: published in 1996.  In this book Robert S. Kaplan and David P. Norton develop and describe the Balanced Score Card
column6: a multidimensional approach to measuring corporate performance that incorporates both financial and non-financial factors.  The Balanced Score Card method of Kaplan and Norton is a strategic approach and performance management system that enables organizations to translate a company's vision and strategy into implementation
column7: working from 4 perspectives:  1. financial perspective
column8: 2. customer perspective
column9: 3. business process perspective
column10: 4. learning and growth perspective.  - Financial perspective: Kaplan and Norton do not disregard the traditional need for financial data. Timely and accurate funding data will always be a priority
column11: and managers will do whatever necessary to provide it. In fact
column12: often there is more than enough handling and processing of financial data. With the implementation of a corporate database
column13: it is hoped that more of the processing can be centralized and automated. But the point is that the current emphasis on financials leads to the "unbalanced" situation with regard to other perspectives. There is perhaps a need to include additional financial-related data
column14: such as risk assessment and cost-benefit data
column15: in this category.  - Customer perspective: recent management philosophy has shown an increasing realization of the importance of customer focus and customer satisfaction in any business. These are leading indicators: if customers are not satisfied
column16: they will eventually find other suppliers that will meet their needs. Poor performance from this perspective is thus a leading indicator of future decline
column17: even though the current financial picture may look good. In developing metrics for satisfaction
column18: customers should be analyzed in terms of kinds of customers and the kinds of processes for which we are providing a product or service to those customer groups.  - Business Process perspective refers to internal business processes. Metrics based on this perspective allow the managers to know how well their business is running
column19: and whether its products and services conform to customer requirements (the mission). These metrics have to be carefully designed by those who know these processes most intimately. In addition to the strategic management process
column20: two kinds of business processes may be identified: a) mission-oriented processes
column21: and b) support processes. Mission-oriented processes are the special functions of government offices
column22: and many unique problems are encountered in these processes. The support processes are more repetitive in nature
column23: and hence easier to measure and benchmark using generic metrics.  - Learning and Growth perspective includes employee training and corporate cultural attitudes related to both individual and corporate self-improvement. In a knowledge-worker organization
column24: people are the main resource. In the current climate of rapid technological change
column25: it is becoming necessary for knowledge workers to be in a continuous learning mode. Government agencies often find themselves unable to hire new technical workers and at the same time is showing a decline in training of existing employees. Kaplan and Norton emphasize that 'learning' is more than 'training'; it also includes things like mentors and tutors within the organization
column26: as well as that ease of communication among workers that allows them to readily get help on a problem when it is needed. It also includes technological tools such as an Intranet.  The integration of these four perspectives into a graphical appealing picture have made the Balanced Scorecard method a very successful methodology within the Value Based Management philosophy.  In addition to this book you may want to consider the following books on the subject: - Robert S. Kaplan. Alignment: Using the Balanced Scorecard to Create Corporate Synergies. - Paul R. Niven. Balanced ScoreCard Step-by-Step: Maximizing Performance and Maintaining Results. - Paul R. Niven. Balanced ScoreCard Step-by-Step for Government and Nonprofit Agencies. - Nils-Gran Olve. Performance Drivers: A Practical Guide to Using the Balanced Scorecard. - Robert S. Kaplan. The Strategy-Focused Organization: How Balanced Scorecard Companies Thrive in the New Business Environment. - Robert S. Kaplan. Strategy Maps: Converting Intangible Assets into Tangible Outcomes. - Robert S. Kaplan. Putting the Balanced Scorecard to Work. - Robert S. Kaplan. The Balanced Scorecard: Measures That Drive Performance

column1: The slow man of Coetzee's novel is Paul Rayment
column2: who in the opening pages we encounter flying through the air having been knocked off his cycle by a young motorist. The story then follows Paul's recovery from the accident
column3: as a consequence of which his freedom is severely restricted. When he goes home having been released from hospital he is allocated care nurses and it his relationship with one of these nurses
column4: her family
column5: and the mysteriously appearing Elizabeth Costello that form the central theme. Sixty plus year old retired photographer Paul is divorced
column6: and is not a man without needs
column7: the need for love and sexual fulfilment. He falls for his nurse
column8: Croatian Marijana Kokic
column9: a robust and capable woman who comes across
column10: perhaps as much because English is not her first language
column11: as a little abrupt. Paul also becomes involved with Marijana's entire family
column12: and especially Mariajna's sixteen year old son Drago
column13: handsome
column14: confident
column15: charming and polite. The elderly novelist Elizabeth Costello makes a sudden appearance as if from nowhere and imposes herself upon Paul
column16: and she then becomes a constant feature for the duration
column17: acting it seems as Paul's conscience (for a short while one wonders if she is real or if she exists only in Paul's mind). What is her motive
column18: she appears to be very knowledgeable about Paul and the Kokics
column19: but is her interest purely altruistic? Paul's relationship with Elizabeth wavers from loathing to tolerance
column20: and maybe more. This is a most endearing story; it is easy to see how Paul becomes infatuated with Marijana
column21: who is fazed by none of the very personal and intimate care she has to provide. Paul's relationship with young Drago is touching; he clearly cares very much for the boy and is prepared to demonstrate that in generous practical ways. This is an interesting and unpredictable story
column22: with a gratifying surprise towards the end.

column1: Author David Peitrusza deserves plenty of kudos for his sweeping biography of Arnold Rothstein
column2: the mad credited for fixing the 1919 World Series.  In "Rothstein" we have an overview of the man and his times with perhaps too much of an emphasis on peripheral people and events.  The reader will be regaled by stories of turn-of-the-century through prohibition era gamblers and big time criminals.  Readers will acquire a greater knowledge of the East Coast underworld and some of the prominent figures who walked the line between criminal and legitimate.  From casinos
column3: race fixing and high society's degenerate gamblers to crooks both small time and big
column4: "Rothstein" is an excellent account of the times of  the famed gambler.  Rothstein surely ranks as one of this country's most notorious criminal master minds. As much as I enjoyed the book I would have liked getting to know the man himself a little better.  While readers will enjoy an opportunity to learn what AR
column5: (as Rothstein was sometimes called) did
column6: where and with whom he did it you cannot be sure to understand what made him tick.  His childhood and early years are skimmed over while great detail is given his murder and its subsequent investigation.  Hopefully someone can come along who will provide a fuller view of Rothstein.  For that biographer and anyone interested in a man immortalized by F. Scott Fitzgerald in "The Great Gatsby"  Petrusza's book is a must-read.  Whatever "Rothstein's faults as a biography
column7: it is still a good read and highly recommended

column1: Death in Venice (1912) is a disturbing story
column2: one that is not easy to forget. It is also exceptional literature
column3: a classic of the twentieth century. Thomas Mann's Death in Venice might be best compared to the subtle
column4: psychologically complex fiction of Henry James
column5: Joseph Conrad
column6: and Fyodor Dostoevsky.    In Munich the aging
column7: highly respected author Gustav Aschenbach is in need of change
column8: rest in a new setting
column9: to overcome his growing fatigue that is impacting his writing. While recovering in Venice
column10: Aschenbach slowly
column11: but inexorably
column12: becomes mesmerized by a young Polish boy staying at the seashore with his aristocratic family. Aschenbach is intellectually aware of his growing obsession
column13: but he is seemingly unable to break away. Thomas Mann's somber portrayal of this troubled man is a masterpiece of subtle nuances and psychological intensity.  Thomas Mann's lengthy sentences and complex grammatical structures severely complicate the task of translating Death in Venice. I have read two excellent and yet substantially different translations. The most faithful translation is by Stanley Appelbaum (Dover edition
column14: 1995). This new translation tries to be as literal as possible
column15: carefully preserving the comparative length of the original sentences as well as the internal sequence of each original German sentence.  Contrastingly
column16: the H. T. Lowe-Porter translation is considered the most delightful and readable version
column17: although at the expense of subdividing many of Mann's lengthy sentences. Lowe-Porter's version has been the standard translation for many years.     The Dover edition provides an excellent 10-page commentary
column18: including footnotes

column1: This book of humorous snippets is at least selected by Frank Muir
column2: which makes a change from John Carey. Frank Muir is an elegant and extremely witty and ingenious virtuoso of the English himself
column3: but I still have to wonder what the possible purpose can be of a farrago of miscellaneous excerpts from different authors. I could have understood collecting a nosegay of the witticisms of some particular writer or of some specific school of writing
column4: but this lengthy tome takes in Smollett
column5: Goldsmith
column6: Poe
column7: Jerome K Jerome
column8: Dylan Thomas
column9: Evelyn Waugh and Beryl Bainbridge
column10: to name but a few. The most astonishing absentee is Oscar Wilde
column11: but some of Bernard Shaw's musical
column12: theatrical and artistic reviews are here. I welcome those thoroughly
column13: as I do the excerpt from a review by Macaulay
column14: but where
column15: I wonder
column16: is A E Housman
column17: whose excoriations of his fellow scholars surpass either of them not only in forcefulness but for sheer hilarity. Otherwise the roll-call of the humorous includes many who are predictable
column18: in no adverse sense. I would certainly have expected to find Dorothy Parker
column19: H L Mencken and Mark Twain
column20: for instance
column21: and so I do. Not all the items chosen are from specific authors - the satirical magazine Private Eye is represented
column22: partly by Auberon Waugh under his own name but also by the spoof diaries and letters of the prime ministerial spouses Mrs Wilson and Mr Thatcher
column23: which are anonymous and may be co-operative efforts. Certain other press series are officially under nicknames
column24: but we all know that Beachcomber in the Daily Express was J B Morton
column25: and that Myles Na Gopaleen of the Irish Times is Brian O Nuallain (aka O'Nolan). The authorship of the Peter Simple column in the Daily Telegraph changed from Colin Welch to Michael Wharton
column26: and not to its advantage in general
column27: but the excerpts here are actually the funniest things that I spotted in the whole book
column28: and I imagine they are the work of the former. His maverick right-wing politics are not my own
column29: but I used to find his stuff irresistible. Other contributors are not household names
column30: possibly not even in their own households
column31: but I would certainly have expected such eminent men of letters as Muir himself and the syndics of the Oxford University Press to have known among them that Humphry Berkeley spelt his first name thus and not `Humphrey'.   In general don't expect to roll in too many aisles. This is an anthology of good-quality humorous prose
column32: not a book of gag-lines and one-liners. You may spot here and there
column33: as I did

column36: if we are lucky

column40: nor indeed can I imagine who ever will. I still fail completely to envisage the readership of a work like this
column41: and I would guess its future belongs mainly on the shelves of the more traditionally-minded libraries and in the hands of browsers in second-hand bookshops searching for curiosities.   Alas

column43: but for all I know it may have value to earnest students of Eng Lit and their instructors

column1: This book is a great reference for any owner and is so easy to use. It has saved me a couple trips to the emergency animal centers in the middle of the night. It is written simply to help you know what you can handle and what is a true emergency to take to the vet. If your looking for a more indepth explanation to different diseases and illnesses this isn't an encycolpedia of information
column2: but if you want something that you can easily look up a symptom or multiple symptoms in chart form with a simple solution this is it! It is also wonderful that it tells you what breeds of dogs are prone to what problems to give you a better picture of what could be happening to your dog. Just last week my dog was sneezing very labored and constant and after 10 minutes he wouldn't stop and you could clearly see he was starting to panic but I could see nothing was in his nose but he kept on. After 15 minutes we knew something was wrong he was pacing
column3: and wouldn't calm down and since it was 11:00pm we would have to drive a 1/2 hour to the emergency animal hospital so we had decide something quick. My husbend remembered this book and he looked it up and he had what was called reverse sneezing and it said to give him wet food. We did and he stopped sneezing almost immediately. Just this morning my friend called me to say her dog was lame and had a fever and asked me to look it up and see what this book had said about it. I can't tell you enough how wonderful a book this is!

In THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY
column2: written in 1955
column3: Patricia Highsmith has created a fictional character as memorable as John Updike's Rabbit Angstrom or Arthur Miller's Willie Loman and just as American in Tom Ripley. She has taken the theme used so often by American fiction writers from Hawthorne to Henry James of the innocent American traveling in Europe and turned it upside down since Ripley
column4: who travels to Italy and other places in Europe
column5: is anything but blameless as he murders to get what he wants.   This novel is so much more than a conventional crime novel. Highsmith writes beautiful
column6: to-the-point prose and totally engages the reader is Ripley's exploits. Her writing is reminiscent of both Henry James and Poe--early in the novel Herbert Greenleaf asks Tom if he has read James' THE AMBASSADORS. He has to reply that he has not-- and she can tell as chilling a tale as any writer I can think of. Even though most of us probably have a pretty good idea of how the novel will end
column7: since two films have been made from it-- the French film EN PLEIN SOLEIL (1960) and THE TALENTED MR. RIPLEY (1999)--we share Tom's fears and concerns-- realizing we should know better-- as he tells one lie after another to cover his murderous tracks
column8: piling one indiscretion on another but always landing on his feet.  Highsmith presents the classic love triangle with a twist. Marge
column9: whom Ripley detests and describes her figure as "gourdlike
column10: is in love with the well-off Dickie Greenleaf and dislikes and distrusts Ripley, believing that he is, in the language of the times, a sexual deviant."  Even if you have seen one or both of the films about this most talented character
column11: you'll be intrigued and entertained by the novel.

column2: and in the hands of a lesser author

column4: an author who could write riveting and gorgeous VCR instruction manuals.  The book's scope is grand.  It follows in intricate detail the pulses and patterns of an entire family through four generations
column5: giving us not just a powerful look at the evolution of the family
column6: but of the country in which they live.  The balance between the two is delicate
column7: but Updike's sparkling prose never loses its focus.  Although the details of America's growing pains are ever-present and
column8: even more important
column9: amazingly done
column10: they never overshadow the story of the Wilmot clan
column11: never seem tacked on just for authenticity's sake.  Likewise
column12: Updike's story itself
column13: although it focuses on four individuals from the same clan
column14: effectively utilizes two contrasting symbols that could very easily have become heavy-handed icons: religion and the movies.  In fact
column15: the book begins with two simultaneous incidents: a starlet passing out from heat exhaustion in the middle of filming a movie scene
column16: and a pastor -- Clarence Wilmot -- losing his faith in God with equal suddeness.  From here
column17: Updike strolls through eighty years like a seasoned tour guide
column18: showing us the bits and pieces that matter as this Wilmot family struggles to find its faith again in a world ever more obsessed with the superficial and unreal.  The book loses some steam in the second part
column19: during the story of Teddy
column20: Clarence's clawless son.  This section functions most obviously as a chrysalis
column21: giving the story (and the country) time to mature into something bigger.  Updike's compelling writing keeps Teddy's rather uneventful tale from devolving into something mundane
column22: although there are points where it is a bit redundant.    He moves from here
column23: though
column24: into the life of Teddy's daughter
column25: Essie
column26: within whom the book finds its strongest thematic purchase.  Bred with a "private God" and an insatiable desire for filmdom's fame
column27: Essie grows into a famous film actress who
column28: amazingly
column29: gets everything she prays for
column30: although she doesn't necessarily pray for everything she gets.  One of the latter things is a son
column31: Clark
column32: who headlines the final part of the book
column33: a tale overtly inspired by the Branch Davidian disaster.  In spite of the glaring similarities
column34: the story itself is still well-told (if not
column35: in some parts
column36: a tad hazy) and bristling with import.    Updike's message is not as clear as his vibrant words
column37: but it is certainly as accessible.  Flowing through his smooth
column38: well-pieced narrative is a liquid-crystal meaning
column39: a well-stated (never obvious) point about where true faith goes
column40: if it ever goes anywhere at all.  It certainly isn't a cliched coincidence that the book's most cinematic (and melodramatic) moment is also its most truly soulful.  And for a book with this much spirit (see the last line of Clarence's section)

The book "Astrology
column2: Psychology and the Four Elements" by Stephen Arroyo is an interesting viewpoint of astrology that emphasizes an individual's psychological make-up from an astrological perspective.  Published in 1975
column3: Mr. Arroyo divided the book into two parts.  The first part he entitled "Astrology & Psychology"
column4: which contains eight chapters.  The second part he entitled "The Four Elements: An Energy Approach to Interpreting Birth Charts"
column5: which also contains eight chapters (numbered from nine to sixteen).  What differentiates this book from other typical astrology books is that it is not merely a look-up table for trying to interpret a person's birth chart.  In the first part
column6: Mr. Arroyo compares the works of various psychologists (such C. G. Jung
column7: Sigmund Freud and O. Hobart Mowrer)
column8: physicians (such as Alexander Ruperti)
column9: philosophers (such as L. L. White
column10: Hans Stossel
column11: Irving F. Laucks and Pascal)
column12: biologists (such as Pre Tielhard de Chardin) and writers (such as Goethe) with various astrologers (such as Dane Rudhyar
column13: David Hamblin and Marc E. Jones)
column14: mythological experts (such as Joseph Campbell) and people claiming clairvoyant abilities (such as Edgar Cayce).  From these (and many others whom I have not named)
column15: Mr. Arroyo creates a synthesis to describe a more humanistic and holistic approach to both psychology and astrology
column16: and encourages psychological counselors interested in astrology to utilize tools from astrology to assist in understand their patients.  He also lays the foundation for viewing the zodiacal signs with regard to the seasons of the year in which they fall with their corresponding psychological meanings.  In the second part
column17: Mr. Arroyo describes various astrological components
column18: such as the signs of the zodiac (from a more elemental perspective)
column19: the planets (from an "energy regulator" perspective) and the houses.  He emphasizes that a simple mechanistic approach of chart interpretation often falls short when the impact of the elements themselves are not fully taken into account
column20: as well as not taking into account how particular individuals may make decisions that overcome what might otherwise may be misinterpreted as "difficult" aspects
column21: when they might actually be good.  His descriptions of the elements were well thought out
column22: as were his discussions of elemental imbalances.  In the final two chapters
column23: he touches briefly on chart comparisons between people and the houses.  Overall
column24: I found "Astrology
column25: Psychology and the Four Elements" to be a very interesting read.  I rate the book with 5 out of 5 stars and highly recommend it to anyone who is interested in learning some basics about astrology

column1: I find it very interesting that so many Christians know so very little about the history of their own religion. Notwithstanding
column2: the same can also be said about the Jews and Muslims
column3: as well as others. This is because religious people are generally taught by religious authorities
column4: and not by historians. It's no secret that
column5: although most Christians have one or more copies of the bible at home
column6: a very small percentage of them actually read it.   From what I can tell
column7: it seems like most Christians know more about their favorite celebrities than they do about the man they worship as God.  Take this for instance; how many Christians are actually aware that Jesus was a Jew? Not just by a Jew by association
column8: but a Jew by practice
column9: a Torah-observant Jew? The gospels tell us that Jesus was circumcised on the eight day
column10: studied the Jewish scriptures (he knew the scriptures very well
column11: throughout the gospels he quotes from the Torah
column12: like when Satan tempted him)
column13: attended the Jewish temple
column14: preached exclusively to Jews in synagogues
column15: and celebrated Jewish festivities. He is even called "Rabbi" by his disciples in all four of the gospels.   Furthermore
column16: the gospel of Matthew shows us that Jesus never intended to create a new religion. Jesus tells his exclusively all-Jewish followers
column17: "Think not that I am come to destroy the law
column18: or the prophets: I am not come to destroy
column19: but to fulfill" (Matthew 5:17).   It is also worth mentioning that Christianity did not exist during the time of Jesus
column20: or even decades after his death. If you search for the word "Christian" or "Christianity" in the gospels
column21: you will not find it. Jesus never mentions such words
column22: nor do any of his disciples. The word "Christian" is mentioned a couple of times by Paul in Acts
column23: and once in 1 Peter
column24: but those letters were written more than thirty years after Jesus died.  So the question is
column25: how did this tiny Jewish sect (and mind you
column26: there were several different Jewish sects) become a religion totally independent and separate from its roots? More specifically
column27: how did this "Jesus movement" evolve to become Christianity? Certainly
column28: this transformation did not happen overnight.  To answer this question
column29: L. Michael White takes us on a journey back to first century Palestine - Jesus' homeland - where he examines the social
column30: cultural
column31: political
column32: and religious environment of that time and explains us the effects it had on this "Jesus Movement." There
column33: White also explores the role of the Roman Empire
column34: the beliefs of Judaism's various sects
column35: the influence of Greek culture and religion
column36: and the wars between the Jews and the Romans. By examining the four phases
column37: or generations
column38: of early Christianity
column39: we begin to understand the transition of "Jesus to Christianity."   Besides Jesus and his disciples
column40: many other important figures are mentioned in this book
column41: including their role in shaping Christianity: Ignatius
column42: Clement
column43: Polycarp
column44: Justin Martyr
column45: Irenaeus
column46: Marcion
column47: Tertullian
column48: Eusebius
column49: and others.  In my opinion
column50: this book is profound enough to enlighten anyone who wishes to gain a clear understanding of early Christianity - from an historical perspective
column51: that is. Mr. White proves to be a formidable expert on the subject and shows objectivity throughout this well-written tome.   I highly recommend it! Five Stars.

column7: the fictional heroine in this novel.  Francie is an intelligent and determined girl.  She is a wonderful writer
column8: and has planned to read every single book in her local library.  Unfortunately
column9: though

column14: her mom
column15: younger brother
column16: and dad
column17: all have to live off of only a couple dollars a week.  In order to survive
column18: Francie will have to work hard
column19: and get a job to support her family.   	In this novel
column20: Betty Smith describes in detail all of the characters' personalities
column21: which helps the reader better understand their actions.  She also describes the time period very well
column22: so it feels as if you're actually living back then.  	I really enjoyed this book because it opened my eyes to how different this country was
column23: just less than a century ago.  Few people back then were well educated
column24: and some were even illiterate.  It also made me see how difficult life is as an immigrant.   Francie has to grow up living through all of these hardships.    	I would recommend this book mostly to girls

column1: Laurel and Hardy are the eternal image to many of down-on-their-luck individuals struggling just to get by in this world
column2: and in his book "Stan and Ollie" author Simon Louvish explains why they appeal to us after almost a century has passed since their first film together. In an exhuastive and well-paced dual biography of the world's greatest comedy duo
column3: Louvish provides insights into the two men who jointly comprised a team that was embraced the world over.  Stan Jefferson (Laurel) and Oliver Hardy could not have come from more different backgrounds: Laurel's father was a North England theater manager who dabbled in play-writing
column4: and his son became an actor on the stage just as vaudeville was on its way out and films on their way in. Hardy never knew his father
column5: a Civil War veteran and local celebrity in their part of the state of Georgia. Both men took long routes towards the inevitable pairing
column6: as Louvish demonstrates in what can be felt as a "teaser" of near-misses and almost-rans between the two when they both arrive in Hollywood in the mid-teens. But in 1927
column7: they finally teamed up and started what would become the most celebrated partnership in film comedy.  Throughout it all
column8: Louvish gives us a portrait of the men behind the image that is all the more important to know. Hardy
column9: the jolly fat-man
column10: was actually self-conscious about his weight and struggled to keep it under control. Laurel
column11: the simple child-like companion
column12: was something of a ladies man
column13: and the tales of his multpile marriages (including a series of ill-timed weddings to the same woman over the course of years) make for an interesting glimpse into his troubled private life.  Laurel and Hardy
column14: together briefly during the last days of the silent era
column15: were able to transcend the barrier of sound
column16: and they may well have been meant for the new entertainment form. Louvish details how they not only survived in the wake of other silent performers (Buster Keaton
column17: Harold Lloyd) falling out of favor
column18: but indeed prosper and contribute some of their best material in the early Thirties.  Throughout the book
column19: Louvish intersects accounts of the films they made together with some of the personal details that helped to shape their time together. He also addresses the odd fact of their embrace by the gay community
column20: and Hardy's troubled Southern heritage and what it may have meant to the era of the Thirties (when openly racist portrayals of the black race ran rampant and unchecked). Stan Laurel emerges as a particularly harried figure
column21: as his constant marital troubles become the fodder for Hollywood gossip mavens (a precursor of the current swath of "celebrity marital trouble" stories circulating in today's entertainment-obsessed media).  In the entertaining way he critiques their work (first the golden years at Hal Roach's studio
column22: then later the Twentieth Century Fox and MGM films)
column23: Louvish comes off not as a grumbling critic but a genuine fan
column24: one who has sat through the dreck as well as the highlights. He can be trusted to give the straight story on the flops as well as the classics ("Sons of The Desert"
column25: "The Music Box"
column26: etc). Louvish's style is not the dry
column27: bare-bones approach of more "scholarly" approaches to film
column28: but he has the right amount of reverence to make up for any percieved flippancy towards his subjects. After all
column29: his profile is that of a comedy duo
column30: not an auteur like Kubrick or Godard.  Louvish successfully argues
column31: what's more
column32: that the films of Laurel and Hardy (while not meant to be artistic statements) are worthy of close study and even analysis for their place in easing the country through the Depression and the Second World War (a claim that he puts forth for the lesser Fox pictures
column33: though acknowledging their flaws). What's more
column34: the friendship between Laurel and Hardy is genunine
column35: unlike so many comedy partnerships that seem fraught with tension.  The book is probably the closest we will get to knowing the real Laurel and Hardy
column36: as well as understanding their most memorable films together. It will definitely be the first thing I recommend for L&H neophytes
column37: and for diehard fans as well. Put simply
column38: this is the book to read if you want to know about the greatest comedy duo of the film age.

column1: This novel grippingly illustrates how money changes everything -- people
column2: in particular -- regardless of how good or amoral they were to begin with.  Scott Smith does an excellent job demonstrating how one simple situation can snowball into a catastrophe and how one small irreversible action can lead an ordinarily good man down a path into the darker side of his soul.  I've always preferred reading a book first
column3: before seeing its film adaptation and I'm glad that's what I did with this one.  I don't think a movie-goer can better see -- and feel -- the moral struggles and the characters' humanity than anyone reading this book.  The author really takes you into the lead character Hank Mitchell's mind and makes you want to stay there until you finish his story.

column1: Kirk Varnedoe gives us
column2: in Gustave Caillebotte
column3: not only a beautifully reproduced compendium of the artist's major works
column4: but an unusually insightful commentary on his place in the Impressionist movement. Perhaps  most importantly
column5: he offers a vision of Caillebotte that allows us to see  him as more than a "minor" impressionist
column6: but as an original  precursor of modernism who remained true to his own unique vision despite  the influences of his better known contemporaries. The importance of late  nineteenth century photography
column7: and especially the new
column8: shorter 28 mm.  lenses of the period
column9: on Caillebotte's treatment of perspective are  analyzed in detail through careful consideration of the preliminary studies  for "Rainy Afternoon in Paris" and "Pont de l'Europe".  While the author is forthright in his views of the "unevenness"  of Caillebotte's oeuvre
column10: he makes a strong case for viewing what Varnedoe  refers to as Caillebotte's "internal personal dynamic" as a  driving force behind the artist's shifting styles and artistic innovations.  The illustrations faithfully reproduce the palette and nuances of  Caillebotte's work
column11: still evolving at his untimely death at age 45. An  important appendix catalogues the gift of Caillebotte's extraordinary  personal collection of impressionist paintings to the French state. These  works by Monet
column12: Renoir
column13: Cezanne
column14: Pisarro and others are part of the core  collection of the Musee d'Orsay
column15: reminding us again of Caillebotte's role  as not only a contributor to the impressionist movement
column16: but as a supporter  and champion of its promulgation

The Witch of Blackbird Pond is Elizabeth George Speare's (1908-1994) second novel. It won the Newbery Medal with full votes in 1959
column2: five years after its publication. Similarly to her previous "Calico Captive"
column3: Elizabeth George Speare draws her inspiration for this historical novel for young adults from real events. In "Calico Captive" it was Susanna Johnson's captivity
column4: while in "The Witch of Blackbird Pond" episodes of witch hunting
column5: that had taken place in the Author's hometown of Wethersfiled
column6: Connecticut in 1648 and 1650-51
column7: are the basis for a breathtaking story .  It is 1687
column8: year of fighting of the Connecticut colonies to preserve their Charter menaced by the English
column9: when young Kit Tyler
column10: after the death of her grandfather in Barbados
column11: decides to go live with her only relatives in Wethersfiled Connecticut
column12: one of the many settlements on the Connecticut River. At her arrival  in her new home she finds a colony of Pilgrims of strict confession which reluctantly accept her as long as she "behaves" according to their unwavering rules. Her adoptive family is sincere
column13: but mentally and emotionally closed
column14: except maybe for her cousin Mercy
column15: physically handicapped. Slowly Kit adapts to her new environment
column16: but she cannot renounce her true character
column17: her curiosity
column18: her need of culture and spontaneous affection. She befriends a forlorn and neglected child
column19: Prudence and an old and estranged Quaker woman
column20: Hannah Tupper
column21: two outcasts of society
column22: and because of  her sincere affection and care is accused of witchcraft. Through hardships and real dangers and the help of true friends she finally finds out who she is and what she wants.   Three intermingling love stories make the plot even more captivating and the book is hard to put down once started. All the characters are lifelike and perfectly described and unforgettable
column23: from cousin Mercy (modelled on Elizabeth George Speare's real aunt who was physically disabled)
column24: to Nat Eaton
column25: the nicest
column26: most sarcastic and challenging young man encountered in young adult literature
column27: to Prudence the unpromising child who turns out to be Kit's most successful pupil and ultimate saviour.   I learned many years after having read the novel in 1967 that this book is today used as a text in English classes in elementary and middle school. Surely it contains many elements to dwell upon and it is hard to forget that Elizabeth George Speare was a teacher particularly dedicated to the study of childhood in the early days of American history. The historical setting of the novel is absolutely perfect with real characters such as Sir Edmond Andros and the royalist Rev. Gersholm Bulkeley that play the role they had in history. The detailed historical research behind the book is also evident from many elements: the pointing out of religious differences
column28: the anti-Quaker bigotry
column29: the psychological explanation based on ignorance of the fear of witchcraft
column30: the difficulty of living in a Pilgrim entourage for a person with sound Faith but educated according to different models.  Elizabeth George Spear's knowledge of adolescent problems is evident as well in the way she conveys the sense of feeling a stranger in a different world and in the attempt to fit in while maintaining independence. Another very New Englandish emotion one gets from the book is the beauty of the changing of seasons from the glory of autumn
column31: to the first snow that can be understood only by people who have lived there.  After so many years
column32: I ask myself how much influence can a writer have on children. Elizabeth George Speare had an enormous influence on me in particular
column33: but I think she did on many through the development of an instinct of independence and especially of compassion and acceptance. I want to remember that in the acceptance speech for the Newbery Medal for "The Witch of Blackbird Pond" she said.. "I do not believe a historical novel should gloss over the pains and the ugliness. But I do believe that the hero .. should on the last page.. still be standing
column34: with the strength to go to whatever the future may hold."  Another small notation
column35: near the end of the book there is a recall to the poetry of  Anne Bradstreet (1612-1672)
column36: the first woman poet of American literature
column37: for a long time ignored and forgotten by many and only recently rediscovered in her actuality. Mrs. Speare's citation of her shows us not only her culture and knowledge of early American history but also stimulates the reading of these beautiful poems that immerge us into the atmosphere of "The Witch of Blackbird Pond".

column1: Eric Raymond is widely regarded as the anthropologist of the hacker community. This is Eric Raymond's revised classic with some new material. It is the first comprehensive commentary on the sociology of the Open Source community
column2: and recommended reading for anyone doing business in software development
column3: or running a business that depends on software and the Internet.    Like many of Eric Raymond's colleagues and fellow Geeks
column4: he is clearly a brilliant individual
column5: carried forward by focused effort and imagination. And like many talented people
column6: he is an autodidact; self taught bar some courses in philosophy and mathematics. This is not a criticism. Raymond's career
column7: publications and contribution show amply the intellectual qualities he possesses. However
column8: his lack of training in social
column9: economic and cultural science shows. And
column10: as an insider (he is one of the original tribe of hackers) he is not the best person to make a disinterested commentary on the hacker community.   Great hackers
column11: he tells us
column12: are humble people. A more critical observer would have analyzed the comparative payoffs of styles showing why a loud mouth style - while it might work for some performers or show oriented careers - doesn't pay in this community. This is generally true of communities in which peers are well able to judge the quality of each other's contributions. Faking it doesn't payoff
column13: and looking like you might need to fake it is counter productive. Insofar as the behaviour of chief hackers is humble
column14: we learn more about the social economy of hackerdom than about distinctive individual personalities.  Despite many insights
column15: Eric Raymond is wrong in his principal analysis. Why
column16: he asks
column17: do talented people spend years of unpaid work on projects that benefit others for no pecuniary reward? He characterizes hackers as members of a gift giving community
column18: and attributes too much of the hacker motivation to altruism and idealism.   The central problem is not "why do hackers work for no pay?" Rather
column19: why do people work for money? Or
column20: more fundamentally
column21: why do people work? I take it that readers will agree that we can roughly divide our motives into physiological drives (hunger
column22: thirst
column23: need for shelter
column24: sex) and the "higher" needs (self fulfilment and meaning). After satisfying the needs for food
column25: shelter and companionship why do we continue to work at all? If it is to get status
column26: to get power
column27: to feel good about ourselves and similar
column28: then money beyond basic needs is unnecessary. Onassis once remarked "Without women
column29: all the money in the world is worthless." Some of us work to become wealthy
column30: and we trade that wealth for status
column31: power
column32: respect and admiration
column33: and perhaps we use our wealth to get women
column34: sex and occasionally love. If this is what these motives are for
column35: then even the higher needs are secondary to sex; or
column36: as evolutionary psychologists tell us
column37: are all about reproduction.   Money is a means. If I can earn status
column38: power and respect directly
column39: why waste time with money? Of course
column40: money is fungible. That means it can be traded easily for a great many things; a big house and a luxury car
column41: perhaps. But possessing these is merely another way of obtaining status
column42: power
column43: respect
column44: admiration and sex
column45: if not love.   Why am I writing this review? By my own dispassionate analysis
column46: I am advertising my capacity to say sensible things and I am making a reputation; this is an asset in the social and commercial market place. Amazon might like me for doing this
column47: but they would be mistaken to think that I write reviews out of altruism directed at Amazon; at least not defined in any metaphysical or moral sense. Sociobiologists denote some social instincts "altruism" but these are operational definitions of instincts as Machiavellian as any scheming tactician can be said to possess; in that sense I may be an altruist. Hackers too
column48: for their work is not unlike my book reviews. Hackers trade in an economy that differs not one jot from the money economy
column49: and Eric Raymond
column50: in so far as he supposes it to be a fundamentally different kind of economy
column51: is mistaken.   Likewise the account of hacker commitment to lofty ideals are not any more credible - but also not any less credible - than the mission statements and codes of ethics written by CEOs of major corporations. Among hackers are people as likely to steal code as are others to donate code; to write viruses as to write Fetch Mail. An anarchic disrespect for some of our more widely accepted conventions for protecting property rights is a characteristic of hacker mentality; not one that we should admire. Of course
column52: honourable idealists are found among hackers; Eric Raymond is clearly one of them. Take
column53: for example
column54: the Open Source Initiative that is largely his work. What an outstanding contribution that is! Clearly he is passionate about his beliefs and ideals. But honourable idealists are found among entrepreneurs too
column55: also successful ones
column56: and even among politicians. Let us not delude ourselves about what it is the really motivates us and our fellow travellers.

column1: First of all I want to confess that I am John Maxwell junkie. I not only thoroughly enjoy his books but they help me in becoming a better person. column1: The novel begins a short time prior to September 11

The main character of the novel
column3: young ill-fated fighter Ahmed Jan

column5: it's made all the worse by the assassination of revered Northern Alliance leader Commander Ahmed Massoud at the hands of al- Qaeda in chapter 2. Ironically
column6: in this their darkest hour
column7: the Qaeda attacks on New York and Washington D.C. turn out to be salvation for the Tajik
column8: Uzbek and other groups of the Northern Alliance who are resisting the cruel Taliban domination. Within weeks
column9: U.S. Special Forces
column10: Air Force
column11: Navy
column12: and other military units sweep the Taliban out of Kabul
column13: Taloqan
column14: Kandahar
column15: and other major cities of Afghanistan and put them on the run
column16: along with their al-Qaeda guests
column17: into the Pakistani tribal territories along the Afghan border. Ahmed Jan finds a mysterious communiqu in the coat of an al-Qaeda messenger and
column18: along with ruthless Mujaheddin fighter Mustafa and old
column19: rigid holy man Mohammajon
column20: gets swept into an adventure that spans the globe from Islamabad to Amsterdam to Venice to Seattle to Vancouver to Karachi and back to Kandahar. This engrossing epic story includes CIA operatives and Special Forces soldiers interwoven with three love stories with very different endings. The adventure concludes with a movingly heartrending
column21: surprise finale. I highly recommend this book for both women and men who are fans of international thrillers novels

column1: Lee Strobel's meticulously compiled "The Case for Christ
column2: attempts with reason and educated pedigree what the earliest Christians accepted on faith and experience: Jesus' life, death,Resurrection and divinity and, with them, human history's defining moment.  Strobel's writes in an investigative reporter's vice-tight format, pulling grisly examples from years in crime reporting to reveal evidence styles proving his case (circumstantial, historical, psychological, medical). He introduces his forensic, scholastic, and theological experts by listing their degrees, teaching posts, and authored books. He fires challenging questions raised by everyone from avowed atheists like Antony Flew to liberal movements like the Jesus Seminar which consider Jesus' resurrection, death, and much of his life allegorical.  At each chapter's ends, the respective expert testifies to his Easter experience. Craig Blomberg, whose insights grace the book's first chapters on eyewitness evidence, mentions scholars have been converted based on Scripture's physical, historical truth. Philosopher/theologian Gary Habermas finds his students comforting him with Resurrection's promise even as his wife lay dying of stomach cancer. Theologian Louis Lapides is interviewed in Strobel's powerful chapter on Jesus filling the Messiah's fingerprint" promised throughout the Old Testament He tells how that decision saved him from addiction yet alienated him from his traditional Jewish family roots.  Some evidence will easily convince
column3: from Jesus' documented appearances after rising to Matthew's record of women (whom ancient Jewish custom found unreliable as witnesses) being first to see Him alive. Other
column4: more linguistic attempts (such as the order of blood and water flowing at Christ's side) may confuse
column5: although Dr. Alexander Metherell explains episodes of Jesus' bleeding throughout His passion.   But Strobel and the experts' most powerful testimony comes from lives of the Apostles and early Christians during their early Roman persecution
column6: and how they chose deaths over denial of the One Who they'd seen alive and whole after His grisly
column7: humiliating crucifixion. How many people would change their way of life
column8: let alone die
column9: for One so disgraced and something they believed a lie?  GK Chesterton once wrote
column10: "Theology is only thought applied to religion." So how many could a factual "Case for Christ" convince
column11: let alone convert? Luke
column12: a companion of St. Paul whose terse
column13: detailed Gospel is cited for proofs throughout this book
column14: quotes Jesus' chilling last words of a parable
column15: "And (Abraham) said unto (the rich man)
column16: If they hear not Moses and the prophets
column17: neither will they be persuaded
column18: though one rose from the dead." (Luke 16:31)   But Strobel took his reporter's gift for chasing truth
column19: and the new Christian life he gave his family after his wife's and his own conversion
column20: and used those tools to dispassionately prove his life's passion. This book looks to convert skeptics and cynics not with fervor or flowery language
column21: but with natural logic proving the supernatural. Be the jury having read it
column22: but Strobel's is the most powerful
column23: popular argument yet for Scripture as accurate
column24: historical
column25: definable truth.

column1: This was really my 'practical compilerbook' winner (bought in 1999)
column2: until I discovered in 2004 "Programming Language Processors in Java: Compilers and Interpreters" by David Watt
column3: which I like more.  If you're looking for a theory book about compiler design I would recommend 'Engineering a compiler' by Cooper et al.  This book offers a nice compiler (including x86 code generator and debugger!!)
column4: for a simple language.   The problem is that the compiler is written in C++
column5: and if you are more familiar with Java you could better buy the book I recommened above.  An advantage of this book is that it also covers rare topics
column6: such as debugger implementation.  A disadvantage is that this book show a lot of code. Actually
column7: all code is printed in the book (as far as I know). That's why it's a big bibble.   The greatest disadvantage of this book is that it doesn't introduce new concepts. It offers a recursive descent parser (difficult to maintain)
column8: instead of much faster table driven parsers
column9: or recursive descent parsers made by a generator (ANTLR).  However
column10: this is a great starter for C++ people new to compiler design. Java people would I recommend to buy the book of Watt as recommended above.

A recent work by MacPherson on the battle of Antietam attempts to locate the turning point in the Civil War. Reading this work one wonders if the whole history of abolition is not a series of endless turning points against eternal delays. This very cogent work by someone acquainted with the facts is an invaluable expose of how politics actually works in that scarface Uncle Sam's 'democracy' of equals. Giving the history and gritty details of post-Reconstruction politics dominated by the Bourbon elites
column2: it is essential reading for anyone attempting to decipher the legacy of the Civil Rights movement this period prefigures
column3: and starts to anticipate. Histories of Roosevelt's presidency don't always make clear what was going on
column4: and the obstacles he faced. Nor do we quite assess the effect of the Second World War on the economic context behind Jim Crow in its ad infinitum history of domination
column5: political manipulation
column6: and class and racial struggle. We can see the great tide turning in the thirties and forties
column7: as the struggle begins just to recoup the ground lost in the 1870's and after
column8: Lyndon Johnson's voting rights bill a resurrection of the same failed bill of the Redemption era. Out of many issues in this very useful book is a reminder of how Lyndon Johnson
column9: extremely adept in this Lost Cause dominion
column10: was deftly able at the right moment to get the job done
column11: if it has been done. With this history
column12: keep your eyes peeled. We could be far short of 'done'

The utopian promise was wishful thinking and the inclusion of the son (the  agressor) thoughts seemed out of place when we know so little of through  most of the novel. It's a great introduction to Gordimer's work
column7: but I'm  going to investigate her earlier
column8: aparthaid period novels to get a better  sense of what she actually writes

column1: A Room With A View is a novel not only about the journey to find true love
column2: but also about the difficult decisions one is faced with when one must decide to either listen to the expectations of others
column3: or their own heart.  In this novel the main character
column4: Lucy takes a trip to Italy with her cousin
column5: and upon her arrival meets the Emerson's.  Lucy belonging to the upper class of society thinks she could never have an attraction to someone of the lower class
column6: like the Emerson's. Love was something Lucy was hoping to find in Italy
column7: but as soon as she arrived back to her home in England she promptly became engaged to Cecil
column8: a man of the same social class as her. Lucy soon realizes that she is not truly in love with Cecil
column9: and discovers that she is in love with George Emerson. Everyone Lucy knows expects her to marry someone wealthy and proper
column10: like Cecil
column11: but instead of listening to what others expect of her
column12: Lucy listens to her heart
column13: and allows herself to be in love with George.  Throughout Lucy's journey to find true love Forster conveys the message that others expectations cannot guide one to the path of love
column14: only one's heart can. I recommend this book to anyone who struggles when faced with making the decision of following others expectations
column15: or following their heart. This novel will teach its readers that what one truly desires is the only escape to genuine happiness.

"The Mouse That Roared
column2: directed by Jack Arnold, is an entertaining satire about the fictional Duchy of Grand Fenwick, a tiny European monarchy which may remind viewers of such real countries as Liechtenstein or Monaco.  With his country facing bankruptcy, the prime minister of Grand Fenwick announces his clever plan to declare war on the United States of America; his intent is to lose the absurdly uneven contest and reap the benefits of post-war American aid.  But things don't go quite as expected.  Mouse" opens with a whimsical animated title sequence that effectively sets the tone for the rest of the picture.  This is followed by a funny faux-documentary sequence about the fictional duchy
column3: and then by the actual story.  The film is a splendid showcase for the great Peter Sellers
column4: who plays three characters
column5: all citizens of Grand Fenwick: the scheming prime minister
column6: the venerable duchess
column7: and the mild-mannered commander of the duchy's pitiable army.  Sellers is absolutely brilliant; he creates three wonderfully distinct characters
column8: and it's especially fun to see the scenes where these characters interact with each other.  His performance(s) alone make the film a classic in my reckoning.  I found "Mouse" to be an enchanting and enjoyable film
column9: full of absurd images and amusing lines.  The marvelous sets
column10: costumes
column11: and props are full of wonderful details that make the film a delight for the eye from start to finish.  And despite its comic tone
column12: the film touches on some very serious issues that remain timely.  I think of "Mouse" as a gentler cousin to the classic "Dr. Strangelove
column13:
another military satire that stars Peter Sellers in three different roles; together I think the films would make a great double feature
