column1: I am developing a course in the History of Technology in America for my local community college
column2: and find this book an invaluable resource.  There is a hard-back one-volume edition as well as a soft-cover two-volume edition available.  The authors hail from Harvard
column3: Yale and MIT
column4: with backgrounds in history
column5: politics and technology.    This is an American history with a difference.  While the student and instructor will find the basic chronological outline of American history that is familiar
column6: the development of themes here often draws in much more explicitly than the normal text the issues of technological innovation
column7: scientific discovery
column8: manufacturing and business development as engines for growth and progress in the course of American history.  The authors state in their introduction that Americans 'have long considered this penchant for innovation a distinguishing feature of their culture and history.'    Technology in terms discussed here is hardly confined to the modern age.  For example
column9: very early in the text the authors state that the development of maize/corn 'was perhaps the most important plant-breeding achievement of all time' - the creation of a stable staple food crop that was adaptable and resilient spurred the growth of civilisation in dramatic ways.   Technology includes that related to architecture (from the earliest buildings in the Native American cultures to modern skyscrapers
column10: bridges and underground complexes)
column11: agriculture (the aforementioned maize development being but the earliest of these examples)
column12: transportation technologies (from canals to railroads to automobiles and aircraft)
column13: medical technologies (from early hygiene and vaccine developments to modern pharmaceutical and genetic innovations)
column14: information technology (telegraph and telephone to digital and internet)
column15: and much more.  History is naturally selective
column16: and any history text is going to have to walk the fine line between being thorough in development and being comprehensive in scope.  The whole work weighs in at well over 1100 pages (inclusive of index and appendices)
column17: which is a lot of material for a two-semester course that will include supplemental readings.  As an overview of American history
column18: it hits the high points well and develops many sidelines of interest.  My own particular teaching responsibilities for this will be to students who are primarily interested in technical education - this method of developing American history has more appeal for this audience
column19: given its more direct applicability to their courses of study.  In the two volume edition
column20: the first volume covers the pre-Columbian scene in the Americas through to the era of Reconstruction following the Civil War; the second volume goes through the presidency of the current George W. Bush
column21: and includes issues of 9-11 and the issues of ongoing wars against terrorists.   There are CD-ROM supplements that come with the books
column22: which include many helpful elements for the students
column23: as well as some multi-media offerings.  These are keyed to chapters in the text.    The text is written in an interesting and informative manner
column24: with appropriate use of humour and wit as situations permit.  For example
column25: from the text on the exhibition in London's Crystal Palace in 1851
column26: the authors write:  'Among the winners was the New York firm of Day and Newell
column27: manufacturers of locks.  In one of the more flamboyant competitions
column28: an employee of Day and Newell successfully picked the locks of several well-known English lock makers
column29: while an English locksmith failed to pick Day and Newell's locks.  The American won a cash prize for his efforts
column30: while the Bank of England
column31: whose vault he opened
column32: subsequently placed an order with Day and Newell for a new set of locks.'  The text is supplemented by a very generous sampling of graphics
column33: pictures
column34: woodcuts
column35: maps
column36: charts and other colourful elements.  Every page has some element of colour and something to make it visually interesting apart from the text.    This is a wonderful book for undergraduate courses in American history as well as for general readers who want to refresh their knowledge of American history.

column3: and later became full-length books; while they cannot supplant the longer works

column5: such as  prostitution
column6: drugs
column7: gangsters (Brian Martin's study of the Green Gang is especially strong)
column8: labor turmoil and political intrigue.  But the in-depth analysis and data shows that for most residents
column9: the city was a place of hard work

column13: but this is a superior edited book on a perenially fascinating place

column1: Through Gates of Splendor is a gripping account of the true story of 5 missionaries martyred in the jungles of Ecuador. Sound familiar? That's because it's the same (basically) story recently popularized by the film End of the Spear.  If you watched the movie and the story moved you

column4: that guy could write!  My favorite of Jim Elliot's quotes comes from his diary
column5: reflecting upon trying to serve God in the U.S.:  "The problem of meeting a culture with truth from God is the most difficult kind of thing. Once comes as a renovator
column6: a conditioner of society
column7: and society is in no mood to be conditioned. The fixedness of the human mind is the 'wall of Jericho' to Gospel preaching. God must shake
column8: or there will be no shaking." (p. 20)  It's high time God shook things up...and it's high time we stop getting in the way.  The book is an inspiring source of faith
column9: hope
column10: and sacrifice. God's glory has certainly shone through the tragedy. The blood shed that day has certainly been a seed planted
column11: watered
column12: and cared for to a miraculous fruition of God's love and peace among indigenous tribes.  Read it! You'll be better for it. .

This is a wonderful novel filled with effective imagery and stunning descriptiveness. I found the chapter where the town sheriff

column1: This book has its flaws.  As other reviewers have noted
column2: it is rambling and disjointed.  While I believe that his facts are mostly right
column3: there are points where he may have come to the wrong conclusion because of a lack of familiarity with aid processes.  Certainly
column4: he over-generalizes based on anecdotal evidence.  Aid in Somalia is probably not exactly the same thing as aid in Chile.  The existence of some venal people in an organization does not mean that everyone in an organization is venal.  Maren is too quick to dismiss people as acting only in their own self-interest
column5: even to the point of being internally inconsistent.  He spends a lot of time passing out blame
column6: and not always where it belongs.  While he is pretty sure that NGOs should be blamed for carrying out bad projects
column7: he doesn't seem to realize that they are under contract with USAID.  USAID can terminate projects unilaterally; NGO sub-contractors can't
column8: both legally and practically.  On the one hand
column9: he steams about patronizing attitudes towards Africans
column10: and
column11: on the other hand
column12: says that it was "not their fault" that recipients stole aid funds in massive amounts
column13: but the fault of those who made aid available to them.  (What could be more patronizing than assuming that adults can't be held responsible for their own behavior?)  Does the fact that aid workers have to convince Congress to give them funding by pointing out the advantages to the U.S. and legislators' constituents really mean that the aid workers were never serious about their humanitarian goals?  The fact that it sometimes reads more like angry blurting than balanced or reasoned scholarship is a shame
column14: because there is a lot of good material here and good points being made.  But it is important to read
column15: particularly now
column16: where there is  renewed clamoring for more funds for aid to meet the Millennium Development Goals.  Maren clearly
column17: accessibly and authoritatively explains why more money does not equal more development; worse
column18: can be destructive.  These points are made elsewhere by others
column19: but are usually buried in dry academic papers that speak in euphemisms.  Anyone who wants to work in development should read this book.  Maren can be forgiven for being angry.

column21: and conflicting

column28: California
column29: and Iceland is virtually pollution free

column31: the 1995 Safe Shopper's Bible lists Halibut from California as a Red Light fish (the worst possible rating). The listed contaminants supporting that rating are DDT

column36: despite the availability of new (and conflicting) information.   2. This new edition lists Salmon in its Green Light section as follows:  "Salmon from Ireland and the United Kingdom is virtually pollution free."  "Pacific salmon (chum

column41: Oregon

column43: once again

Another disappointment is that a large number of fish listed in the Safe Shopper's Bible are nowhere to be found in the new edition of Diet for a Poisoned Planet. column1: George writes convincingly about the need to remove the landlord from the equation when dealing with industrial ownership and taxation. He argues that the private ownership of land should be the sole source of government revenue
column2: releasing trade from the shackles of corporate taxation
column3: individuals from income and other indirect taxes and shifting the burden to the landed classes. It seems a justifiable premise to charge landlords for the land they occupy as inevitably land values rise only as a consequence of society as a whole and not due to anything the landlord contributes. Businesses pay ever increasing rents to a landlord who cares little whether that business is profitable or not. George proposes a single land tax but fails to answer the socialist question about industrial democracy and worker's particpation and control

column1: `Insatiable' is a collection of anecdotal memoirs by Ms. Gael Greene of the overshadowingly broad brimmed hats and long time food writer and restaurant critic of `New York' magazine. While the 51 chapters do touch on Ms. Greene's life before `New York'
column2: they generally stay very close to their `New York' wellspring
column3: her column
column4: named `The Insatiable Gourmet' by magazine editor in chief
column5: Clay Felker.  The most immediate comparison which comes to mind is to the three volumes of memoirs by current `Gourmet' editor in chief
column6: Ruth Reichl who
column7: for several years
column8: sat in Craig Claiborne's chair as principle restaurant reviewer for `The New York Times' and whose most recent book
column9: `Garlic and Sapphires' deals entirely with her `New York Times' restaurant reviews and her tactics for maintaining her anonymity while in the hunt for excellence at New York's finer eateries. And
column10: as similar as these two women's careers may be
column11: the differences make both bodies of work that much more interesting.  While Reichl
column12: the younger of the two by at least a decade
column13: grew up in New York City and learned French at a very early age
column14: her professional culinary journalistic career was shaped on the west coast
column15: firmly under the influence of the American food vanguard lead by the California vintners
column16: Alice Waters
column17: Jeremiah Tower
column18: and Wolfgang Puck. Greene grew up in provincial Detroit
column19: but had her culinary instincts formed by the emerging community of French restaurants in New York City. Her center of culinary gravity was in the dining rooms
column20: kitchens
column21: and cellars of the great French culinary establishment. She even admits that she came late to the California culinary movement. To her credit
column22: as soon as she had her first experience of Alice Waters' cuisine at `Chez Panisse'
column23: she recognized that there was something important going on by the Pacific coast.  Reichl's first two volumes of memoirs are more strictly biographical than `Insatiable' in that they are strictly chronological. Reichl's revelations about her life are also unusual to me
column24: at the time
column25: for the remarkable candor about her sexual life. Madame Reichl was a Den Mother compared to Ms. Greene
column26: whose title refers not only to her culinary appetites
column27: but to her sexual appetites as well. I won't dwell on this much
column28: but her exploits make me and most average Americans feel like monks or nuns in comparison.  These sexual exploits include dozens of famous figures from the culinary world
column29: but they also include several notables from Hollywood. As a hint
column30: I will reveal that Ms. Greene tells the tales of how she landed in bed with two very big leading men
column31: both of whom appeared together on the cover of `Time' magazine. And yet
column32: Ms. Greene can be remarkably circumspect about the details of many liaisons.  It is interesting to see the difference in reaction to some of the major figures both have met. Danny Kaye appears in both narratives
column33: however
column34: he is a much bigger part in Ms. Greene's story
column35: as does James Beard
column36: Julia Child
column37: Craig Claiborne
column38: Pierre Franey
column39: and M.F.K. Fisher
column40: as Ms. Greene was able to encounter all these people while they were still at or near their prime
column41: unlike Ms. Reichl
column42: who did not arrive in the `big time' at the `Times' until most of these people were retired or gone. The stories regarding Danny Kaye are especially nice
column43: as I have been pining for more information on his culinary abilities ever since I read Ms. Reichl's report of a dinner he prepared in his custom build `kitchen theatre'.  Ms. Greene also fills in a lot of information on some of the more romantically interesting figures in the culinary world. For example
column44: when one reads other accounts of the lives of  `Le Bernardin' founders
column45: Gilbert and Maguy LeCoze
column46: you are left with the feeling that their closeness can only be explained by a particularly `unnatural' sexual relation. Miss Gael assures us in no uncertain terms that both Gilbert and Maguy were decidedly conventional (At least for young French natives) in their sexual behavior
column47: each with their own one or more partners
column48: including
column49: for Gilbert
column50: Ms. Greene herself now and then. She also sheds light on the fact that suspicions to the contrary
column51: Pierre Franey was a complete heterosexual
column52: with no erotic connection to culinary colleague
column53: the well-known homosexual
column54: Craig Claiborne.  One feature of New York dining on which Ms. Greene and Ms. Reichl agree is that most of the high end venues are far too inclined to give preferential treatment to favorite customers
column55: most of which are celebrities. One of the most disagreeable cases appears in the chapter about the literary watering hole
column56: `Elaine's' which became popular among celebs almost by accident
column57: when `Harper's' editor Nelson Aldrich (not even Nelson Algren)
column58: wandered in and stayed awhile
column59: bringing a few other literary luminaries along in later visits. And
column60: while we are less likely to be inconvenienced by this
column61: this is just as true of Parisian venues as those in the Big Apple.  Like Ms. Reichl
column62: Ms. Greene sprinkles in a few recipes here and there
column63: after every second or third chapter. These are interesting
column64: but I found her passing remarks about dishes within her text to be far more evocative
column65: as when one New York maestro filled a baked potato with creamed chipped beef and how Gilbert LeCoze prepared such simple fish dishes
column66: because he never received the kind of training which showed him how to do elaborate preparations (Under Eric Ripert
column67: `Le Bernardin' is still a temple to simple
column68: fresh fish cooking).  While Ms. Reichl's last book may be more interesting to the serious foodie as it deals in much more detail with the specific restaurants
column71: Ms. Greene's book has far more interesting and far more lascivious information about the lives and loves of the culinary great in New York and France.  A delicious tart of a read!

column1: I love this movie. This has got to be one of my all-time favorites. It's hilariously funny and every time I watch it I get this fuzzy feeling inside and it makes me go 'Squee!
Guillermo del Toro (who directed last years phenomenal Pan's Labyrinth) seems to be at his best when dealing with the paranormal; indeed
column2: he has the uncommon gift of making the fantastic seem plausible. This film contains some of the most haunting and believable images I've seen on screen
column3: and their efficacy was heightened by the director's understanding of when enough is enough. Ghost stories of any kind fail when the real or imagined ghost is absurdly presented. Most of today's contemporary "Master's of Horror" fail miserably.  It is 1939
column4: and the Spanish Civil War is in its final days. Carmen and Doctor Casares run an orphanage for boys (one does wonder
column5: why no girls?). The institution has a remarkable feature: in the middle of the courtyard is a bomb
column6: the tip of which is embedded firmly in the ground. The bomb fell from the sky during a raid
column7: but never exploded. It sits there
column8: disarmed yet immovable
column9: as a reminder of the violence in the outside world.  Carlos
column10: a ten year old
column11: is left at the orphanage
column12: and though Carmen argues that they have no resources for more children
column13: she accepts him and assigns him to bed number twelve
column14: the bed that Santi slept in until the day he disappeared
column15: which was the same day that the bomb fell from the sky. Carlos
column16: predictably
column17: begins to see visions and shadows
column18: and at first
column19: it isn't understood whether these come from his mind or if they are real. One night
column20: a shadow tempts him from behind a bed curtain
column21: and when Carlos pulls the curtain back
column22: the shadow is gone. But the pitchers of water in the boys' room have fallen from their stands and break
column23: and when the other children awaken
column24: Carlos and Jaime each take a pitcher to refill in the kitchen. Carlos sees footprints in the spilled water. When the boys reach the kitchen
column25: Jaime pumps water for his pitcher
column26: and waits outside for Carlos. As Carlos is pumping
column27: a rack of scissors in the kitchen falls and makes a loud noise. Jacinto (Eduardo Noriega
column28: Open Your Eyes)
column29: the young caretaker who was once an orphan himself here
column30: comes to investigate. Carlos flees down into the cellar to hide
column31: and there he encounters the shadow that taunted him. He is touched by his phantom in the cellar
column32: and we see
column33: before anyone else
column34: that this image is real. It is a boy
column35: no older than Carlos
column36: with the upper left portion of his forehead cracked open
column37: and pale
column38: blood seeping upwards as if the body was underwater. After touching Carlos
column39: the ghost quickly disappears
column40: but a voice says
column41: "Many of you will die."  It is a prophecy that demands fulfillment.  There is gold in the orphanage
column42: gold that Carmen and Casares give to those that will be called Nationalists
column43: in support of their cause. Jacinto knows of this gold
column44: and he wishes to steal it for himself. Not only is he bedding Conchita
column45: the beautiful young cook (and Jaime's wide-eyed crush)
column46: but he is also taking Carmen as a bedmate. It is an unusual coupling; Carmen was the principal when Jacinto was an orphan there
column47: and she has a wooden leg that she must set aside to accept him. (Some small irony there.) When they partner
column48: Jacinto takes and replaces one key from her large ring of keys to see if it will be the one to open the safe that holds the gold.  With Jacinto
column49: a ghost may be the least of their worries.  This is an excellent film
column50: one better appreciated on the second viewing. I've heard it compared to The Others
column51: but I doubt such comparisons would have been made if the director and writer of The Others
column52: Alejandro Amenabar
column53: was not also Mexican. While they are both ghost stories
column54: they operate under completely different rules. I highly recommend this.  4 stars rounded up to five for the convincing "paranormals".

column1: When I was first interested in learning about Judaism I really didn't know much. This book was recommended to me
column2: so I got it. I kind of liked the first part and found some good information
column3: but I got very bogged down just over half way through when it started to get into the ritual a bit more. I didn't really understand what I was reading so I put it down.   After some years and learning from other sources I picked this up again. I was amazed at how my perspective had changed. It suddenly had meaning and I find myself going back to it again and again for guidance and understanding in many areas.   If you are new to Judaism
column4: you might have a hard time with this book
column5: like I did (I found "To Pray as a Jew" even harder)
column6: but if you know a bit from other sources and you are really interested in really understanding and remembering the details this is a very good source.   Here is an excerpt to demonstrate how difficult it can be to understand
column7: but how there are gems therein:   "A Jewish definition of holiness may be put in these terms: Holiness does not lie in the ascetic
column8: saintly withdrawal from life
column9: or in excessive denial to oneself of all human pleasures
column10: of in the repression of all human drives. It consists
column11: rather
column12: of full participation in the stream of human community life
column13: sharing the joyous as well as the sorrowful experiences which life has to offer
column14: denying to oneself no legitimate pleasures; but at the same time so developing one's sense of discernment as to be able to distinguish and choose the right from the wrong
column15: the true from the false
column16: the good from the bad
column17: the sacred from the profane
column18: the pure from the impure
column19: and the clean from the unclean. The greater the sense of ethical-moral-religious discrimination
column20: the greater the holiness of the individual."  If you have trouble with this book I would recommend you skip the parts that are difficult for you or just put it aside for a while
column21: but keep it nearby because it is very useful later. Many think of it as a classic. I don't think you'll find a compilation of information like this anywhere else. There is no book I'd recommend in its place.

column1: Stephen Kinzer writes a great history book that reads like a spy thriller. He details the rise of oil and the importance it has for the west in the two World Wars and the fact that the British were unwilling to give up control of the Iranian Oil Fields.  Eventually
column2: American policy formulated by the Dulles brothers
column3: leads the American CIA into overthrowing Mossadegh's government in 1953 and putting the Shah into power. For about 26 years the Shah runs Iran
column4: but the inner frustration and anger towards American involvement into Iranian politics results in the 1979 hostages taken in Tehran. Kinzer does an excellent job with the details of the CIA and British intelligence as he clearly describes what was going on with the Iranians
column5: the British and the Americans throughout the overthrow of Mossadegh.  If you want to find out why Iran views the British and the United States governments with such disdain
column6: this book will open your eyes to what occurred 50 years ago and why terrorism today has its roots in our involvement in Iranian political affairs of that time

column1: "Death Comes to the Archbishop" is one of the most moving books I have ever experienced.  In many ways the American Southwest has never been protrayed better than in this Willa Cather.  Quiet as the desert itself
column2: this story evokes the all that is best about the people and the places of that area.  Magical is the best word I can use for this book.  Magical in its evoking of the American Frontier.  Magical in its representation of a humble servant of God.  Magical in Cather's language and images.  Magical in its use of language.  One of my favorite novels.  My introduction to Cather and her unique style.  Whatever happened to writers like this?  Any Cather book is also a treat in audio forms.  The beauty of the language is even more apparent when you can hear the words and the images.  Magic

column1: One has to read Zubrin to understand the future of manned space flight. He charts out an achievable path to reclaim our destiny
column2: which has been otherwise derailed by self serving politicians and our own success in the cold war.   The Case for Mars is a readable and easily understandable exposition of the Mars Direct plan which will allow us to bootstrap our way to the red planet and beyond without neccessarily depending on bloated agencies of a government which is choking itself in red ink. Mars Direct relies on proven twentieth century technology to launch proven nineteenth century fuel and air plants to achieve a cheap and self perpetuating colony in space.  But his most brilliant exposition is his simple plan to make people WANT to return to space.  We already see the early results of his vision on how to to give incentive for space to private enterprise
column3: via compeditive prizes for reaching stepwise goals. In 2004 we have seen NASA take second place in space related achievement to Burt Rutan's commercial enterprise
column4: Scaled Composites. Following Rutan's successful launch of the X-Prize winning Spaceship One he unveiled his plans for placement of a commercial space station and so we are finally back on the path to space. If Rutan and other commercial adventurers continue to follow Zubrin's steps we may well see our children opening the Martian frontier

With just 266 pages of conceptual clarity  the mild and unassuming Friedrich Hayek reveals the bogeyman
column2: Karl Marx
column3: to be the brutish boor that he was.   Marx had no concept of human nature or more specifically
column4: of individual psychology.  Individuals did not exist for Marx
column5: only "classes".  And Marx had no interest in human beings as they now exist
column6: but only as they will come to exist in his imagined utopian future.  In Hayek one senses a genuine fondness for humanity as it now exists.  Hayek realizes that human nature is not perfect and is not perfectible
column7: yet he has a genuine desire to make life better for all people. His humanitarian impulse is behind the political economy he finds necessary and sufficient for the betterment of humankind: capitalism.   I've wrestled with Marx for many years without being able to get a theoretical grip that would pin him down.  The wiry and sinuous thought of Hayek has provided a hammer-lock that Marx can't break. I plan to read
column8: and re-read this little book and will purchase a hard-back edition to better stand up to the wear and tear.  Those readers without some background in economic theory may find this book a bit difficult at times.  My advice
column9: just keep plowing through the pages
column10: skimming where you must.  For the most part the book is quite readable.  And there are so many gems of wisdom the book is well worth the time and expense even if you read and understand just a few pages.  Having said all this
column11: I have not touched on Hayek's economic theory and why I think it superior to Marxist theory.  In the social sciences
column12: as well as the hard sciences
column13: a theory displaces another theory when it better explains the facts.  History is the laboratory of economic theory. Marx's theory that a classless society
column14: communism
column15: would grow out of and replace capitalist society has been proved wrong by the facts of the 19th and 20th centuries.  Hayek's theory that a capitalist economy (given the limits of human nature) is the best system yet known to humanity
column16: has proved to be true.

It analyzes exactly what you would need and need to do to fashion your own batcave. This book tells you what to put in your utility belt and where to get one.  I have read only one of Mr. Grisham's novels, but the nature of this horrible story compelled me to purchase it and devour it in on a recent flight from LA to NYC. This well-told tale of a frightening miscarriage of justice
column3: occuring not in some third-world country under a despotic military ruler, but in late 20th-century Oklahoma, will leave you shaken to the core of your being. If you are at all familiar with the criminal justice system, and not, as some of the reviewers of this book seem to be, simply by watching CSI" or other such drivel on television
column4: you will appreciate the skill with which Mr. Grisham researched his material and presented it clearly
column5: concisely
column6: and with a minimum of finger-pointing. That is rare indeed today in the world of non-fiction writers. I also do not understand why some of the reviewers of this book have called is "depressing
column7: or dark" - it's not a novel
column8: it's real life
column9: folks! And yes
column10: it is about some of the most miserable of human beings
column11: our death row inmates - and there are no clean-cut Hollywood stars
column12: or pretty locations
column13: or sexy starlets to pepper its pages. This is a dirty
column14: blood and guts story out of the heartland of America and should strike fear into the heart of anyone who reads it
column15: as we are all potential victims of a system than can sometimes go terribly awry. As an attorney
column16: I applaud Mr. Grisham for making Ron Williamson and Dennis Fritz's story more widely available to the public. It shames the jurisdiction of Ada
column17: Oklahoma and the corrupt police force
column18: prosecutors
column19: and judges who sentenced these innocent men to over ten years behind bars on the flimsiest of evidence while neglecting to pursue the most likely suspect in the crime. Justice? Absolutely not
column20: for even after their charges were dismissed
column21: the only apology they received from the great state of Oklahoma was in the nature of a monetary settlement
column22: and then only after a civil rights suit had been filed on their behalf. This story should be compulsory reading for every law student and attorney in this country - a reminder how much power can corrupt and sway "reasonable men" to commit atrocitices in the name of justice. I rarely give any book a five-star rating
column23: but "The Innocent Man" clearly deserves to be read

column1: Prime Cuts: There Are No Accidents
column2: They Say Love Is Blind
column3: I'm Not Lisa  Wasting no time
column4: recent high school graduate Erika Jo releases her debut CD in less than a couple of months after she has been crowned 2005 Nashville idol.   On this eponymous record
column5: Jo ups the ante on contemporary pop-country with a state of the art production with an occasional nod to the ancient tones of rustic country.  Save for the occasional fiddling and steel
column6: stinging guitars and forceful percussions over bubbly pop tunes are the order of the day.  Pride of place is also given to the chockablock lineup of songwriters on this record
column7: this includes fellow artists such as Katrina Elam and Rachel Proctor plus tried and true hit writers Danny Mayo
column8: Sunny Russ
column9: Blair Daly
column10: Stephony Smith
column11: Dave Berg to name a few.  Nevertheless
column12: the spotlight is Jo's energized and spirited vocals:  Jo has the vocal tenacity of LeAnn Rimes and the mellifluousness of a young Brenda Lee.  Hence
column13: it's no surprise Jo has been the darling of the million plus viewers of Nashville idol.     In the spirit of Nashville idol
column14: where contestants tend to sing their heads off
column15: Jo's full throated voice is on full display on the midtempo "Good Day for Goodbye."  Refusing to take the mediocre as an excuse for a dying romance
column16: "Good Day for Goodbye" finds a determined Jo finally calling it quits with her paramour.  Such a strong-willed woman theme resurfaces again on the Sunny Russ' penned "Strong Enough."  A popish anthem dedicated to stating over again
column17: there's camaraderie that ought to identify with anyone who has had been emotionally sliced and diced.  Written by Jim Collins and Stephony Smith
column18: "Go" continues the theme of taking chances. "Go" has an inherent Tanya-Tucker bluesy grit that makes it quite an experience to be beheld.   However
column19: Jo is even better in the album's slower and more subdued moments.  From the first tinkling of the piano on Jessi Colter's "I'm Not Lisa" (which is also covered by Elizabeth Cook on her "Hey Y'all" and Faith Hill on her forthcoming "Homefires" CD lately) every note of this cheating ballad is mesmerized with an emotional intensity that wouldn't let go.  The plangent "They Say Love is Blind" brings to mind Lorrie Morgan's "I Guess You Had to Be There
column20: as Jo witnesses her former boyfriend kissing a new love on a romantic street.  This is heart rending stuff at its best.  On the other hand, There Are No Accidents
column21: is a gorgeous love ballad that finds Jo philosophizing on the epitome of her relationship.  Listen especially to how her astringent voice imparts wisdom as she sings: I used to talk about coincidence/And how true love is only found by chance/Now I look at you and I'm convinced/There are no accidents."    Nevertheless
column22: there are a few tracks that veer on the contrived side. Lead single "I Break Things" has perhaps one of the most clich and trite lyrics: "Rain is wet/The desert is dry/That's the way it'll always be/Fire is hot/It's dark at night/The sun comes up in the east."  I am sure an eight year-old can come up with better lyrics than that.  Perhaps befitting to Jo's age
column23: "Love Is" is at best juvenile and it sounds out of place with the abovementioned gems.  "Who You Are
column24: one of those inspirational type uptempo numbers, about searching for one's identity is so blend that one gets lost straightaway as the first note strikes.  Erika Jo" is a promising debut from a young lady who can sing and when she wants she is able to burn vocally with vivid passion that is hard to resist.  Nevertheless
column25: she's often let down by some of her songs.  Perhaps
column26: they were hastily chosen and if she has had more time
column27: this CD would have had been even better.  Jo is a name to match and with such a copious crowd of fans behind her
column28: over a million can't be wron

column1: Those who come to A HAPPY DEATH after THE STRANGER tend to note the similarities in plot and theme that relegate they believe the former to the latter as a juvenile attempt--not bad maybe
column2: but not the real thing either. Such a judgment is overhasty. The Mersault of A HAPPY DEATH may or may not be the Mersault of THE STRANGER. Both live in Algiers and both wander aimlesslessly in life
column3: seeking a philosophical underpinning.  Both kill a man
column4: and both suffer for it.  But such a facile comparison omits a great deal that suggests when Camus took up the pen again a decade later
column5: he has more in mind than a handy earlier book from which he could self-[...].  The Mersault of A HAPPY DEATH has a first name
column6: Patrice
column7: who is poor and seeks a way to battle a losing effort with time that his poverty proves a hindrance. He finds a rich cripple and kills him
column8: and steals his money
column9: which he uses to work out the details
column10: however bizarre
column11: of a philosophy that involve his finding happiness. The other Mersault seeks happiness too
column12: but with him he already is "happy" in the sense that he knows his place in the universe
column13: which he sees as a disordered self-contained field of entropy from which he concludes that nothing makes sense and everything is meaningless. This Mersault does not need to steal money to reach a higher state. Patrice Mersault seeks to elevate himself to reach a higher state that he feels money is the key and murder is the means. His later counterpart would find it amusing that his namesake would bother to look outside himself for anything. Patrice
column14: could he but jump into HIS counterpart's book
column15: would feel
column16: not amusement
column17: but rage at someone who has no purpose in life except to keep doing what he is doing.  Both Mersaults share some surface traits
column18: but in the final analysis
column19: they are no more than two distinct individuals who share a name and a few piddling details of their surface lives.  And perhaps this is what caused Camus to take up the pen with his twin Mersaults: to show his readers that the universe cannot mean more than what you put into it or what you don't.

BAD BEHAVIOR features nine stories involving protagonists who feel incomplete and are constantly searching for some human connection.  The collection opens up with the daring story

column17: Joey

column1: Picking up on a few key theoretical points not included in other reviews. Harvey is pressing an academic point within the broad Marxian tradition-- a point which also has broad practical consequences for confronting imperialism's latest incarnation. A central contention is that the capitalist world has been experiencing a crisis of overaccumulation since about 1973
column2: as evidenced by a lack of opportunities for profitable investment (for which
column3: by the way
column4: he offers no statistical data
column5: but which is not at issue here). Growth prior to the 1973 watershed
column6: he argues
column7: was driven by expanded reproduction with the US exercising hegemonic authority as a result of its WWII reorganization of  old European colonialism. However
column8: for various reasons (chiefly Vietnam era inflation) this regime broke down. At that point
column9: he argues
column10: the much-marginalized neo-liberal thinking of von Mises and von Hayek began to get a sympathetic hearing and commenced its long march through the institutions of the capitalist world. This new strategy utilizes neo-liberal  measures
column11: such as trade and finance liberalization (IMF
column12: World Bank
column13: GATT
column14: et al.) to force open hitherto closed or regulated foreign markets
column15: thereby helping to employ  surplus capital. A related tool is to force devaluation upon a target economy
column16: enabling foreign investors to buy cheaply and improve opportunity for increased profit margins. Thus
column17: in broad outline
column18: a new form of imperialism has arisen
column19: one that remains similar to its classic colonial predecessor in that it still seeks to relieve accumulation problems at home by shifting profitability problems abroad
column20: sometimes forcibly so.  Harvey descibes this new imperialism as accumulation by dispossession
column21: a controversial description since dispossession in classic Marxist thinking is supposed to be restricted  to the primitive forms of accumulation of times gone by. Still
column22: the evidence is considerable given the wave of privatization of formerly public assets (water and education
column23: in particular) in many parts of the world
column24: (think also of recent attacks on Social Security). Indeed
column25: these institutional measures  inside and outside the US
column26: do in fact resemble the classic "enclosues" of capital's earlier
column27: more primitive stage. Recent attacks on formerly state-sponsored economies such as Yugoslavia's and Iraq's amount to further cases in point. But
column28: again
column29: this revived dispossession need not depend on military invasion; the subtler form attacks through the avenues of capital markets and state-sponsored privatization. Though the current period is dominated by dispossession
column30: Harvey points out that accumulation by reproduction still continues. In fact
column31: he asserts
column32: the two are `organically' related and `dialectically' connected
column33: for which however he offers scant elaboration.   The practical upshot of imperialism by dispossession is to force a  shift in anti-imperialist thinking away from the familiar strategies that challenged the pre-1973 expanded reproduction regime. That earlier response stressed organizing the proletariat into a political force in order to seize state power in behalf of socialist principles. Movements outside that exclusive strategy were considered secondary at best
column34: and counter-revolutionary at worst. Though this effort failed in its primary task
column35: the author points out that it's hard to conceive of Europe's social democracies or America's New Deal as taking place without the single-minded drive of communist party politics. However
column36: these methods are now clearly inadequate for confronting  neo-liberalism and its capacity to bypass both organized labor and state power (consider neo-liberalism's sabotage of France's Mitterand in his effort to deepen socialist programs in the 1980's). Instead
column37: current forms of resistance are much more diverse and localized
column38: as evidenced by Mexico's Zapatista movement or Bolivian resistance to water privatization schemes. If there's a central rallying cry among these diverse groups
column39: it's opposition to `globalization'
column40: at least in neo-liberal form. Generally
column41: the central challenge facing anti-imperialists
column42: as Harvey sees it
column43: is to combine the wisdom of former strategies with the developing modes of today-- a not inconsiderable task
column44: to say the least.   All in all
column45: this is a stimulating read. There is much to digest
column46: especially in grappling with the theoretical aspects. It's important to point out that Harvey approaches the topic as a critical observer and not as an economist
column47: a fact which some may count as a fault since many of the conclusions rest on economic data. Still and all
column48: the work remains an important prism for examining current trends

column1: This film is a collection of short clips (taken from newsreels
column2: propaganda films
column3: and mainstream movies) made by/for/about the Vichy government from 1940 until the liberation of Paris in 1944.  This is a modern (1993) attempt to paint a picture of the Vichy government that they may have painted of themselves.  I found this to be a fascinating window into how the Vichy government viewed themselves.  The style of the film is
column4: in many ways
column5: similar to `Triumph of the Will'.  There are fiery speechs about duty
column6: honor
column7: hard work
column8: basic/traditional values
column9: sacrifice
column10: etc.  There is clearly some effort to create a personality cult around Petain as well.  An effort was apparently made to place Petain above petty political machinations of individual parties (i.e. he was above partisan politics and only represents France's interests).  Complex issues of the day are framed very simply
column11: with an `us-versus-them' dogma.  Many of the clips are blatant racist
column12: anti-Semitic propaganda (i.e. during discussion of the `Jewish Question' there is video of rats coming out of a sewer).  There is also a great emphasis on the energy of the youth
column13: how they will be the saviors of the future.  One thing I found particularly interesting about this film was the repeated line of argument taken by Petain and the other Vichy functionnaires that France will suffer less pain by siding with Germany than against
column14: so France should work with them.  Finally
column15: I found it interesting how
column16: as the war progressed
column17: the justifications of the Vichy regime to support Germany became progressively more ridiculous.  The place in history for the Vichy regime is still a hotly disputed subject several generations after the war.  This film certainly does not explore many of the moral ambiguities of the Vichy era
column18: it paints the Vichyites simply as Nazis.  I give it four stars simply because it is a propaganda film and there is only so much to be learned from this type of film.  I am not an expert on the Vichy era
column19: but this film left me with more questions than answers (perhaps this was the point of the film?).  The film itself is fast paced and the various clips are seamless woven together.  There is some English commentary
column20: but most of the discussion is French with English subtitles.  Overall
column21: a good inside into Vichy France and highly recommended for anyone interested in WWII or French History in general.  Finally
column22: if you are looking for a good (French) film that actually explores some of the complexities of the occupation check out the film `Uranus'

column1: In this book
column2: Rene Girard tries to propound a new theory of sacrifice
column3: religion
column4: myth
column5: tragedy
column6: incest
column7: and taboo. His basic thesis is that sacrificing a scapegoat was the way primitive societies overcame the natural lawless violence (mimetic desire) of their societies by re-directing it on a sacrifical victim.  To explain his thesis
column8: Girard studies sacrifical rites of the world and especially the ancient world and primitive societies
column9: as also the tragedies of Sophocles and Euripedes
column10: particulary those that pertain to Oedipus and Dionysos. He gives a radically new interpretation of Oedipal tragedy taking Freud into a radical new direction
column11: and explains why incest was feared because of its effect of leveling distinctions. His interpretation of Dionysos is singularly brilliant.  According to Girard
column12: leveling distinctions or eliminating differences removes the safegaurds that contain violence in primitive societies (he states that our safegaurd - law - is itself based on the concept of sacrifice to restore order) and hence anything that levels distinctions was feared. He also shows how the various sacrifical animals or men have the chracteristics of inside/outside with respect to the community.  The book does have its drawbacks
column13: but is intellectually stimulating. The main hallmark of this work is that it de-mystifies religion and especially represents the most convincing theory of sacrifice and tragedy I have read.  As far as the drawbacks are concerned
column14: the theory is rigorously argued in the beginning but thins out towards the end of the book. As a theory of sacrifice
column15: his evidence supports him. As an interpretation of certain myths and as an explanation of incest and African kingship rites
column16: he is close. However when he streches it to explain origin of religion
column17: kinship rules
column18: all kinds of rites etc.
column19: his argument often wears thin.  There is also a question of unanswered ethical import - is sacrifice legitimate because it prevents communities from collapsing

column1: Donald Davis
column2: in his book Lightning Strike
column3: has made an effort to clarify the historical record by providing details that demonstrate
column4: once and for all
column5: who was responsible for shooting down the bomber that carried Admiral Isoroku Yamamoto over Bougainville in April 1943.  Much of the book focuses on events leading up to the mission to find & shoot down Yamamoto's aircraft.  This first portion of the book introduces the members of the strike team that was responsible for intercepting & destroying the target.  Tom Lanphier
column6: one of the pilots on the mission
column7: claimed that he was solely responsible for shooting down the aircraft carrying Yamamoto
column8: but Davis brings forth the new evidence that was not available to contemporary historians immediately following the war demonstrating that Lanphier not only did not shoot down Yamamoto's plane by himself
column9: but probably had no involvement whatsoever in shooting down the aircraft.  The book is an easy read & certainly does provide new insights into the 60+ year old controversy over who was responsible for ending Yamamoto's involvement in World War II.  I would change only a couple of things about the book - the first is very minor: at the conclusion of the book
column10: Davis tells us that Rex T. Barber was responsible for the destruction of Yamamoto's bomber
column11: but then he ends the book by writing "In 2004...Rex Barber deserved 100 percent credit for shooting down Admiral Yamamoto.  The resolution was accompanied by legislation to clear the path for Congress to finally award Barber the Medal of Honor."  Unfortunately
column12: he does not tell the reader whether or not the deserved medal was ever awarded (as it turns out
column13: the legislation was still pending as of the publication date of the book).  The 2nd thing I would change is a little more significant - I would have changed the length of the book by removing some of the pre-mission background information about the members of the strike team.  The details presented make for interesting reading
column14: but (in my opinion)
column15: don't really add to the understanding of the  mission itself.  I would strongly recommend this book to anyone looking for an understanding of what happened to Admiral Yamamoto on that fateful day

column1: I am twice unqualified to review this work. I am not part of the target audience as I am not a woman
column2: and am not a student of Kabbalah or Jewish mystical practices.  Still I read the work out of my interest in Jewish life and experience
column3: and in my concern for the Jewish future.  I therefore strongly recommend that the reader of my review take it not as any kind of definitive statement
column4: but rather as a subjective view which needs to be complemented by the views of others. The book is  a strange amalgam
column5: but not an ineffective one . It is at once a kind of spiritual autobiography
column6: and introduction to Jewish mystical teaching and practice. It is also and the second part of the work is devoted to this a set of exercises or teachings on how to achieve the meditative and spiritual aims which are Besserman's goal. In this last part of the work there are four Paths given
column7: a Path of Letters
column8: of Emanations
column9: of Sounds
column10: of Song and Dance. My review does not relate to these paths
column11: and whether they are practically useful or not.  The story which is told by Perle Besserman is of a girl who found herself confined
column12: and not understood in a traditional religious framework. Her  desire for a closer connection and understanding with God she felt was thwarted all through her time of religious studies. She especially felt that the Judaism she lived and learned was primarily for men. And that women were to be their footstools.  She rebelled against this and went on a path of spiritual exploration. As I understand it she abandoned Halachah
column13: living by Jewish law and instead searched to find her own spiritual truth and way in life. This led her to seek out some of the great Jewish teachers of modern times. And there is an interesting section on her experience with Rabbi Tzvi Yehuda Kook in Israel. There is also most importantly for her the story of her friendship and learning with the Rabbi and Teacher who is considered most responsible for the revived contemporary  Jewish interest in meditation and  mystical practice
column14: Rabbi Aryeh Kaplan. Even with him she was not content with the traditional emphasis on seeing things from the male point of view
column15: and was urging toward his developing or revealing a way of feminine relation to the Divinity
column16: or perhaps the feminine aspect of the Divinity. Kaplan tragically died before her course of learning with him could be completed
column17: and she thus had to strike out on other paths. These included ways of mystical practice which do not have their source in the Jewish tradition. One central source of her learning has been the Buddhist tradition.  All of this leads her to finding her own way of transforming mystical teaching which brings her to a deeper and more fulfilling sense of her own spirituality.  My  summary  does not do justice to the richness of Besserman's language and learning. She has studied for years and in a way the most valuable part of the book is the knowledge that she does convey about Kabbalah.  With all this
column18: I found her story a not very encouraging one.  On one level
column19: on the level of an individual's struggle and effort and attainment of learning
column20: I admire what she has done. But on the level of a contribution to the world which she comes from
column21: to Jewish communal life
column22: and to the Jewish future I find her enterprise seriously lacking.  For what I see in it is simply another individual rejection of Jewish communal responsibility and feeling.  There is one incident in the book in which Besserman returns to visit an old friend. This friend was with her a 'rebel' against the narrow 'Beis Yakov' religious school  world. But instead of like Besserman getting out of
column23: she went back deeper into it. She even married the boy Besserman had a youthful crush on. When Besserman visits her she is an ultra-orthodox woman tied down by her growing family
column24: sunk in the traditional woman's role. Their meeting results not in a renewal of friendship but in a misunderstanding in which Besserman is unfairly chased away.  Yet the picture presented here
column25: and the drastic dichotomy between the two women and the future seems to me a false one. The fact is that the Jewish people today are suffering from a ' birth dearth.'. We are after the Shoah in demographic decline. And the burden of having a family is not something which is as presented here
column26: a somehow ' valueless limiting thing'.  Today far too many  Jews are escaping into either 'no Jewishness at all ' or a kind of ' non- historical selfish individual spiritualism' which contributes nothing to Jewish community
column27: history and future.  There is a Jewish people also. And the absence of relation to it is felt most strongly in this work.

column4: that got me through Calculus. I just wish the rest of the world would have lived up to the high ideals expressed in these books....   _I recently reread this tale after many years. I was amazed at how "nondated" it was. Heinlein has a perfect description of cell phones and cell towers. Something else finally hit me too- this is where Gene Roddenbury got most of his ideas for Star Trek. Heinlein actuallly uses the term "the Federation." His Interplanetary Patrol is obviously the inspiration for Star Fleet with it's noble ideals
column5: multi-cultural make-up (in 1948)
column6: it's commitment to keeping the peace

column8: the Annapolis graduate. The way that the organization is entirely composed of officers and officers in training- that's also pure Star Trek. Heinlein wrote of all this almost 20 years before the television show aired....   _It used to bother me that the Heinlein that wrote this book and the Heinlein that wrote _Stranger in a Strange Land_ and all that came afterward seemed like two different men. I now think that I understand that too.

column1: The authors did an excellent job of writing and presenting an accurate description of sexual practices in our country
column2: including its history - obviously
column3: an extremely difficult undertaking.  In early America
column4: the main deterrent to premarital sex was the fear of pregnancy and the severe consequence of social ostracization.   However
column5: sexual desire was always there for both men and women
column6: regardless of social class or standing.  Control over casual sex lay in the hands of family and/or the mores of society.  Premarital sex was not permissible for anybody.  In practice however
column7: this sexual taboo applied mostly to women.   Men - on the other hand - had choices!  They were the creators (always with god's help - of course) and enforcers of the rules and laws governing our social behavior!  Talk about one-way streets!   Margaret Sanger (born 1883) was a nurse who fumed over this grossly unfair treatment between the sexes and began the search for a dependable means of birth control.  She needed a means or device that women could use to counter their fear of unintended pregnancy.  She locked horns
column8: clanged heads with the law (mainly the Comstock laws)
column9: and ended up with a number of warrants issued for her arrest.  She fled to Europe while a number of her friends and associates kept the ball rolling in search of a positive
column10: reliable means of birth control for women. In 1915
column11: she announced she was returning to America to surrender and stand trial on the charges against her.  As soon as the courts heard of this
column12: all charges against her were dropped; the bureaucrats feared her like no other woman. For the first time
column13: women got reliable birth control devices
column14: and could begin to enjoy sex outside of marriage
column15: without fear
column16: just as surely as men did.   By the turn of the century
column17: in order to finish leveling the sexual playing field
column18: women needed a place to go and a means of getting there.  Two World Wars
column19: one in 1914 and the other in 1941
column20: would provide the answers.

column1: "Over Sea Under Stone" is perhaps the weakest of the classic "Dark is Rising" series
column2: though in itself it's quite a good book. In this
column3: Susan Cooper kicks off her epic fantasy sequence with doses of Celtic legend
column4: a good vs. evil battle
column5: and a hunt for a mysterious
column6: magical treasure.      Simon
column7: Jane and Barney Drew have arrived at their great-uncle Merriman's seaside house for a vacation -- and rapidly become quite bored with the seaside village. But when exploring the attic
column8: they unearth a very
column9: very old map that is somehow connected with the legendary King Arthur. As anyone else would do
column10: the kids begin the search to find a golden grail that is somewhere nearby.      But they soon find that they are not the only ones who want the map. A seemingly genial pair of vacationers are being slightly too inquisitive
column11: and someone breaks into Merriman's house in search of the map. And Merriman reveals the origins of the map -- and an ages-old conflict between good and evil that hinges on who finds the grail first.      Taken alone
column12: "Over Sea Under Stone" is a solid
column13: even excellent fantasy story. But it's a little out of sync with the rest of the series. However it  sets excellent groundwork
column14: has an intriguing storyline and a good mix of folklore and Arthuriana
column15: and offers us one of the most mysterious and likable "magic mentors
column16: Merriman Lyon. It starts off with every kid's fantasy -- treasure maps and ancient kings -- and rapidly blossoms into something much more.      One of the most noticeable differences between this and Cooper's later books is the writing; the writing in her later books becomes much more verbose and descriptive and magical. Here it's quite stark and plain, without a great deal of detail or mystical mind-blowing. Over Sea" is mostly very prosaic and very rooted in our world
column17: and many important concepts in the series aren't even touched on.       The Drew kids are the sort of siblings that pop up in old E. Nesbit books -- plucky
column18: chirpy and on vacation. There isn't a lot of difference between their individual personalities
column19: although they are quite likable. Their "uncle" Merriman is pleasant
column20: humorous
column21: but at the same time Cooper implies that still waters run deep. The malevolent Mr. and Miss Withers are initially very jovial and kindly
column22: but you can sense something rotten underneath.      The first of the "Dark is Rising" books is somewhat out of sync with the novels that follow
column23: but taken alone it's still an excellent
column24: well-written fantasy adventure

The remarkable thing about this book is it contains so much wisdom in so few words.  It truly lives up to its title - A Manual For Living.    If there is any fault to be found with the book it would be in its brevity.  I have read many books that say less in four times the number of words.  It is really amazing that so many of the truths of living a purposeful life filled with happiness have been around for so long.  We struggle with day to day problems because we fail to seek the answers contained in this book.  It is also amazing that most of todays graduates of institutions of higer learning do not possess the wisdom that Epictetus did.  We seem to have become a nation concentrating on acquiring knowledge without learning how to apply that knowledge.  Epictetus shows us the way to achieve our purpose in life. To achieve freedom
column2: which he says is the ultimate way to live.  Some of the better lessons are: You become what you give your attention to. Think things through and fully commit! A half-hearted spirit has no power.  Tentative efforts lead to tentative outcomes. Wise people on the other hand realise that we are the source of everything good or bad.  It you want all the wisdom without an excessive amount of reading
column3: this book is for you.  It is short enough you can read it weekly and let the concepts sink into your subconscious mind where they can lead you to the life you were designed to live

column5: describe the experiences of six inhabitants of Hiroshima

column9: chapter 5 adds a further 60 pages that enable the reader to trace the long-term consequences of the bomb on the lives of these six people
column10: as well as Japan and the world in general.  The witnesses chosen by Hersey
column11: "who were among the luckiest in Hiroshima" (p87)
column12: insofar as they were not instantly vaporized
column13: burned to a cinder or flayed alive
column14: are wonderfully diverse. Mr. Kiyoshi Tanimoto was a Methodist minister; Mrs. Hatsuyo Nakamura

column18: Mazakazu Fujii and Terufumi Sasaki

column21: as only 65 of the 150 doctors in the city had survived
column22: and most of them were so severely wounded that they could not be of any assistance to anyone. As for the 1
column23: 780 nurses
column25: 654 were either dead or incapacitated
column26: resulting in massive overwork for the small and virtually helpless remaining staff.  "Hiroshima" is of value mostly as a testimony
column27: adding six more life stories to the existing literature
column28: and enabling the reader to form a more complete picture of the aftereffects of the blast. Unlike "Children of the A-Bomb" though
column29: a volume which I recently reviewed
column30: it gains strength from its interweaving of the individual stories
column31: as people meet and lose sight of each other
column32: giving the book a unity and a dramatic construction that is reminiscent of the familiar disaster-movie pattern.  Quite unobtrusively
column33: the author also manages to give us the big picture
column34: through the sparse
column35: judicious use of statistics and other general information. The book thus answered some of the questions I had left after my previous readings on the subject
column36: such as the role of charitable institutions after the bombing
column37: Dr. Sasaki illustrating the work of the Red Cross for instance.  I also wondered whether the Japanese had suffered the same fate as some German civilians in the firestorms of WWII (as described by Jorg Friedrich in "The Fire : The Bombing of Germany 1940-1945"): getting stuck and burned alive in boiling asphalt. Hersey partially answered this question by mentioning that in the afternoon of August 6
column38: "the asphalt of the streets was still so soft and hot from the fires that walking was uncomfortable." So some of the horrors endured by the Germans must have been repeated there too.   This book may well be the best introduction on the market to Hiroshima as seen by the victims. It can be helpfully complemented by the aforementioned "Children of the A-Bomb: Testament of the Boys and Girls of Hiroshima" edited by Dr. Arata Osada; Keiji Nakazawa's 10-volume manga "Barefoot Gen" (a rather ugly but powerful series
column39: which is much superior to the two movie adaptations); Paul Wilmshurst's 2005 BBC documentary on the subject; and Koreyoshi Kurahara and Roger Spottiswoode's brilliant "Hiroshima" (1995)
column40: which seamlessly blends stock films and reconstructions in a dispassionate narrative of the events leading up to the dropping of the bomb.

column1: This second installment in the Coyote trilogy was every bit as enjoyable as the first.  In "Coyote" Mr. Steele presents the story of the first interstellar colonization
column2: cast in a light similar to that of the American Revolution.  The intrepid colonists have managed to escape a repressive right-wing government only to find that they must now defend their freedoms against the efforts of a left-wing government (that has arisen to power in the 200 or so years that have passed on earth) to subjugate the colonists and reap the benefits of the new world via slave labor.  Owing to time-dilation inherent in the travel between the stars
column3: Steele is able to have his original colonists face yet another repressive government and he makes excellent use of the themes and characters presented in Coyote.  The Coyote trilogy belongs to the adventure genre rather than that of  science-fiction.  Sure
column4: there are some elements of science fiction
column5: but this is purely a story of colonization and discovery--discovery not only of geography but of the importance of good government and leadership.  Adventure seems to have fallen out of favor.  Our world is too well understood to support adventure tales.  Honestly
column6: can anyone even get lost anymore?  If so
column7: where is your cell phone?  No
column8: adventure these days requires either an alternate history
column9: a third-world militaristic setting
column10: or going beyond the moon.  Want to go to Everest?  Hire a guide and get in line.  Want to go to space?  Join the crowds.  How about the exotic South Pacific--boring
column11: Survivor has been there and done that.  Our world has lost the spirit of discovery.  We have become more worried about disturbing the local flora and fauna than seeing new sights and paving new trails.  Accordingly
column12: we need to get our butts into space and recapture the spirit of the western expansion.  But enough philosophizing...  Not only has discovery become passe
column13: we have also forgotten the importance of fighting for what we believe in.  In our astonishingly successful economy it has become more important to consume than to discover--more important to celebrate diversity than to seek after truth.  Too many have bought into the fallacy that all forms of government are acceptable--as long as our oil remains cheap.  In the adventure genre our heroes fight for important things--they take risks and explore new places and ideas.  We need much more of this kind of literature
